summary: Now that Chris and his girlfriend, Rose, have reached the meet-the-parents milestone of dating, she invites him for a weekend getaway with Missy and Dean. At first, Chris reads the family's overly accommodating behavior as nervous attempts to deal with their daughter's interracial relationship, but as the weekend progresses, a series of increasingly disturbing discoveries leads him to a truth that he never could have imagined.

reviews.content:
The storyline was gripping and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. The themes explored in the movie, such as racism and social commentary, were very relevant and thought-provoking. The acting was also superb, especially by the lead actor Daniel Kaluuya. His portrayal of the main character's emotional journey was truly impressive.

The cinematography and editing were also very well done. The use of colors and camera angles added to the overall mood and atmosphere of the film. The pacing of the movie was just right, not too slow or too fast, and the suspenseful scenes were executed with great precision.

Overall, "Get Out" is a must-see movie that will leave you thinking long after it's over. It's a great example of how horror films can be used to explore deeper social issues, and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a good thriller.

When the film begins to really crank and ratchet up the dread/suspense it really becomes a mysterious and psychologically daunting experience. 'Get Out' is splendidly directed most of the time however the film would have been far more effective without the deflating comedic relief bits.
A refreshing take on the horror genre back in that time.

Jordan Peele's best movie and one of my top 10 horror movies, Get Out is a scary, confusing, and impactful movie from start to finish with an interesting premise and horrifying scenes.

One of the few movies I can go 6 years between viewings and remember just about everything. There's so few moments in Get Out that aren't funny, interesting, suspenseful, or shocking. It's almost like a kaleidoscope of a movie. It's consistently in a different mood, but also in a cohesive mood the whole time. This was one of my favorite theater experiences ever. I don't actually have much to say on Get Out, but it's one of those movies where an hour and a half feels like 30 minutes since it flows so well.

Horror tension, mystery tension and racial tension blend together into a gripping and formidable nail-biter in "Get Out," the astonishing directorial debut of Jordan Peele. The former half of the comedy duo "Key & Peele" has found a way to both honor and subvert the thriller and horror genres in a way that's unmistakably modern.

In the tradition of "The Stepford Wives" with the twist of "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner?," the story follows a young black man named Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) who goes to meet his girlfriend, Rose's (Allison Williams) parents at their fancy estate where things go from slightly uncomfortable in terms of Chris being black to deeply messed up in one slow but inevitable fell swoop.

With a creepy opening scene showing a different black man getting abducted in a peaceful-seeming suburb, the tone is set immediately that there's cause for concern. Luckily for Chris, Rose is really sensitive to issues of race and prejudice, and even when her parents (Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener) or brother (Caleb Landry Jones) seem to make Chris' blackness into a thing, the two handle it as best as any interracial couple could. The warning signs come in the form of the Armitage family's black help, maid Georgina (Betty Gabriel) and groundskeeper Walter (Marcus Henderson), whose behavior is anything but normal.

Peele sets a tone of creepiness largely with the help of composer Michael Abels, also making his feature film debut. The unpredictable nature of Georgina and Walter as characters, the ever-increasing suspicion of all the white characters and the way Peele keeps you nervous about who or what is just outside the frame fuel the fear and paranoia as well as if not better than any horror movie featuring more overtly malevolent forces does.

Kaluuya, in a role that will deservedly put him on the map, gives a performance that will connect with viewers who identify with Chris as a man trying to feel comfortable while out of his element experiencing strange things, and those who truly understand Chris' experience as a man of color undergoing the very same events. It would be fascinating to know the different ways a black viewer would experience the film compared to a white one, but the most important thing is that everyone will identify with and feel for Chris.

When a little horror film debut like this one gets talents such as Whitford, Keener and Williams, you know the script is good. Peele keeps up the air of mystery a long time even without packing in very many unexpected twists. The awareness of something being wrong but not quite understanding what it going on or why despite getting new information is a real strength of Peele's writing. Then of course there's the brilliant ways that race and the black experience make it into the film. If that weren't enough, Chris' best friend (LilRel Howry) provides comic relief in a way that's stereotypical, yet Peele uses him in unexpected ways. So we get to benefit from Peele's nose for comedy as well.

Not everything adds up by the end of "Get Out," but the film plays out in extremely satisfying fashion. Fans of horror and fans of thrillers who don't mind horror when it's done well should both enjoy the technique and experience. It provides thrills of the pulse-pounding, thrill-seeking and thought-provoking variety and few genre films can say the same.

(Spoilers) Jordan Peele's superb sci-fi thriller is a clever black variation on the Stepford Wives.  Instead of women being replaced by imposter-robots, we have an evil cult of white people, living in Connecticut, who lure black people into their social circle.  Then they drug them; subdue them; and then implant their white brains into the young, strong, healthy black bodies.  It's not hard to read the metaphor here: Peele is criticizing white appropriation of black culture; and white exploitation of the black community as a whole.  I'd say this Stepford Wives remake is actually much better than the original.  Ira Levin's 70s feminist thriller was a bit of a one trick pony.  It played it's hand early, and stayed with it's simple plot to the end.  And it had an ugly heavy-handed finale; where Katherine Ross is destroyed by the evil Stepford Husbands and is turned into a Fembot, with all her friends similarly destroyed.  The ending was so dark it caused many feminists to misread the story as misogynistic.  This was not what Levin intended; he was trying to do a feminist version of Invasion of the Body Snatchers; which decried women's subjugation to patriarchal culture; not celebrated it.  Peele on the other hand keeps you guessing; the plot is more twisty and unpredictable; and he doesn't kill off his hero just to make some point.  (That would have ruined the ending). It's also quite funny.  (Not surprising since Peele is one half of the famous Key and Peele comedy team).  This movie is very entertaining; thrilling, and fun; and it makes nice points about exploitation and cultural appropriation without getting bogged down in its own politics and getting ugly.  It's also nice to see a movie which is in some ways a return to the serious and socially-conscious sci-fi films of the 60s and 70s: Rosemary's Baby, A Clockwork Orange, The Twilight Zone; Planet of the Apes; Soylent Green; these were all Sci-Fi shows and movies which had a point; which had a strong political message attached.  They had some strong criticism of social trends in our culture; or man's foibles in general; or contained observations and lessons about culture and society.  Somewhere along the line; about the time Star Wars came out; sci-fi dropped it's serious and political bent and became mindless escapism; and that was a huge loss.  Hopefully Get Out represents a reversal of that trend.

The 1960s movie Guess Who's Coming To Dinner dealt with a perfectly liberal, upper middle-class, white couple contending with their daughter's relationship with a black man. As challenging as it was for its time, it comes across as positively cosy compared with this movie. Get Out delves much deeper into the innate racism that most people have built into their psyche. It is a genuinely disturbing movie: as much a psychological thriller as a horror, set in rural isolation, away from the safety of a more accepting, multicultural city. On the surface, everything seems innocent enough, but … The disturbing, nonconsensual psychotherapy scene alone should be enough to unsettle anyone. From the strange behaviour of the black help to the uncertainties feared by the boyfriend, with nods to various class and racial stereotyping, no matter how broadmindedly hip you think you are, this should have you questioning your own thoughts and attitudes towards race, and mixed race relationships. This is one movie that pushes aside any notion of coziness to challenge the subject at every level, no matter what race or class you happen to be.

Minha opinião: Um suspense bem elaborado. E com atuações muito boas dos atores, principalmente de Daniel. Com certeza a interpretação dele, fez toda uma diferença para a conclusão final do filme. Um filme de mudança de mente (cérebro) literalmente e sendo usado também hipnose. Uma cidade pequena do interior dos EUA. Onde a filha do casal Catherine e Bradley, usam sua filha Alisson a fisgar tanto homens e mulheres negras, pois a fisiologia deles é mais forte. E desta vez quem ela fisgou? Daniel. Um casal lindo, que vai visitar os pais delas no interior. Ele sem suspeitar de nada vai. Participa da hipnose da "sogra" e participa de uma festa entre os amigos da família. Tipo para apresentar ele para as pessoas, mas ele sem saber de nada. Mas acaba suspeitando o agir dos criados negros da casa e um dos maridos negros que veio na festa. Nesse momentoele começa desconfiar de algo. E tenta ir embora, até que a ele é pego pela hipnose. Quando acorda esta amarrado na cadeira e participando das hipnoses e assim descobrindo toda a trama, até que chega o momento de fazer o transplante dos cérebros e o louco do Caleb que o irmão de Allison vai busca-lo. Ele consegue fugir, mas sera que conseguirá sair vivo da casa? Só assistindo.

'Get Out' was very highly recommended by a friend, also a fellow film enthusiast, and the subject matter of the film really interested me. Add to that a very promising trailer, the award nominations and wins and mostly positive word of mouth (even with the very vocal detractors), and interest was higher.

High expectations were not only met but also exceeded. Apologies for the cliché, but to me that is the best way to sum up my personal experience watching 'Get Out'. Can totally see why it was as well received as it was, though can also see why it has divided audiences on here. While it will never be one of my favourite films, 'Get Out' is among the better films of 2017 and does live up to the hype.

It's an incredibly well-made film visually, with stylish and unsettling cinematography and editing and some disturbingly surreal imagery that adds to, and enhances, the unease and sense of dread.

That the direction was done by a first-time director is a shock in itself, one of the most outstanding debut directing jobs seen in a long time by me. It's nostalgic in its embracing of contemporary and classic horror and also brave in the accomplished handling of the film's combative themes.

Being somebody who considers music important when talking about it, the music looms suitably ominously and fits well. 'Get Out' benefits from an extremely smart and clever script (though 'The Shape of Water' and especially 'Lady Bird' were worthier wins for the Best Original Screenplay Oscar in my view), that takes on a lot of elements and balances them adeptly and the individual elements handled very effectively.

Despite how it sounds, 'Get Out' struck me as more of a thriller with horror and comedic elements. It is highly successful on this front, with the thriller elements being taut, suspenseful and unsettling, the comedic ones being darkly funny and clever and the horror ones being imaginatively shocking and subtly uneasy. There is even some social commentary and interracial themes explored, and done thoughtfully and just about avoids preachiness while hitting hard still.

While all the performances are very fine, it is Daniel Kaluuya's superb lead performance that burns in the memory the most.

My only complaint of 'Get Out' is the too pat and somewhat silly ending that felt tacked on and like it came out of a different film, to me it too ended on a tonally jarring and that's it note.

Until then, the film was this close to being a masterpiece. So it was frustrating that it just missed out on that distinction. Nonetheless it's a great film that is among the year's better ones, brought down by an underwhelming ending. 9/10 Bethany Cox

Jordan Peele hace un trabajo espectacular criticando el racismo actual desde una óptica surrealista pero que metafóricamente narra como de cierta manera seguimos teniendo los mismos juicios y prejuicios que hace 100 años, aunque superficialmente la sociedad sea diferente. Que se hace más evidente en ciertas escenas, como la presentación de la fiesta donde Chris se siente incómodo por no sentirse perteneciente a ella y que se evidencia más con los prejuicios internos de todos los invitados hacia el y que culmina de una gran manera con la frase de "No es lo que dices si no como lo dices", esa escena técnicamente es perfecta, ya que en ella se expone el conflicto interno de la película y se establece el suspenso de la misma; Que gracias al espectacular soundtrack de Michael Abels introduce muy bien al espectador a la agonía de la casa y al encierro de la misma, que por varios momentos llega a ser estresante, conectado muy bien con la gran actuación de Daniel Kaluuya, (que más allá del meme), la escena de la primera hipnotización es brillante ya que específicamente en esa escena demuestra todo su nivel actoral, demostrando la agonía y la incertidumbre del ambiente en el que está involucrado, manteniendo y entendiendo cada escena y como su personaje desde su POV reacciona a las circunstancias, armando el rompecabezas con el espectador. Si tuviera que decir algo que no me encantó de la película sería que por momentos Jordan Peele llega a ser un poco sobre explicativo para que a todos los espectadores les quede claro en conflicto y ciertas metáforas puntuales de la película, que aunque no está mal si llega a conducir a algunos diálogos forzados.  

Jordan Peele y su equipo hacen un trabajo brillante, supieron como construir un mensaje que sin sentirse forzado logra ser efectivo, ya que ataca a la sutilidad, como la escena en la que se presenta el personaje de Andre y a su esposa, que bien podría representar como la gente moldea a las personas y que inconscientemente los aleja de sus raíces. O la escena en la que el personaje de Rod va con la policía, que para mi representa como la polícia no ataca los problemas de toda la gente por igual desacreditando la versión de ciertas personas por como se ven. Get Out, es una crítica sobre el racismo que con tintes surrealistas cuentan una historia que te hará estar al filo del asiento en toda la película, que en su narrativa logra sentirse auténtica. Todos los involucrados regalan un trabajo técnicamente perfecto para que te sientas estresado y pendiente en cada detalle de la misma.

This wasn't quite what I expected - I was expecting more in the way of obvious jump scares (although there were some, not as many as I'd assumed) and gory imagery, even if not strong violent scenes themselves, as I had heard it wasn't so much of a horror film but more a sort of quirky thriller. Its a difficult film to categorise but its certainly eery and unsettling and it does have an atmospheric feel to it. 

It was clear to me that its about racism but not direct racism, not obvious racial slurs as such but about a sort of swept under the carpet form of racism, a sub-conscious kind of it - its hard to explain. It has almost a Hitchcockian feel, with the main character seeming to be made to feel uncomfortable and unwelcome but if he were to say this outloud as such and challenge it, it would be hard to explain precisely why he felt that way. It really is one of those films that you have to see and make your own mind about, I suppose. There is a decent amount of suspense and certainly a heavy dose of tension brewing under the surface, as it were, although if you break it down, for most of the duration the physical things going on aren't necessarily, on their own, that worrying. It could be said that paranoia is at play but I certainly found myself feeling concerned and unsure, as Chris did.

I did feel that the music was, at times, a little over the top, a bit obvious perhaps but I wouldn't say its too big an issue. Its a good film and I'd recommend it if your interested in it, as long as your not hoping for an all out slasher fest type watch.

Jordan Peele's art of interpretation and symbolism is one of a kind, especially if we're talking the horror genre. Simply put - this movie is an absolute must watch! If you enjoy work that's like no other, you'll end up wanting to see this movie more than once, with anticipation for another Peele masterpiece building inside of you. A total fresh take with original story, this movie is interwined with foreshadowing through and through. Everything in it has a purpose, there's a foundation for all that happens. Peele serves the audience a not-so-usual-in-media view on racism through satire with chilling horror elements, which leave you feeling unsettled more than anything. This film doesn't tackle the theme of racism in the classic 'republican' way, just for the sake of checking a box for a character development. It rather focuses on the "passive" racism from 'liberal democrats', which isn't a typical on-screen portray we would see often. It's good to see a piece of media that portrays the reality of those experiences, rather than just traumatize the character with no intention of further plot or actual representation. At the very end, let's not overlook the spectacular casting; Daniel Kaluuya and the way he can act through his eyes should be studied. The scariest part of this movie is, though, how real it actually is.

Everything here was just so meticulously plotted out, it's a delight to unravel as you go through the film. Brilliant performances all around. Effective set-ups and payoffs (the scratching tic, the spoon thing, the deer). The bingo scene was incredibly unsettling. Solid misdirects with the girlfriend Rose being the one to point out the odd, racially clumsy behavior of her family. It's lovely to see inquisitive, competent protagonists that try to learn more and then want to bail once they feel they've put enough of the pieces together. Tying in Chris' backstory with the Sunken Place was absolutely masterful, and is what pushed this into 5 star territory. He sat by doing nothing, watching a TV screen, as his mother lay dying from the hit and run. And in the Sunken Place, where he can't move or speak (where he can do nothing), the only image of the outside world is through a shrunken film frame that looks just like a TV screen would. So good. And the ending fakeout when the cops show up, a great way to just devastate your audience momentarily. Great theme-driven story with excellent execution.

This movie. I honestly cannot begin to state the utter confusion I feel over its popularity. The premise is so incredibly thin as to be a network movie of the week. From beginning to end the story bumbles along the all-too-tread road of white = bad, black = innocent and "trapped." It is a tale that has been told 1,000 times in the last 50 years.  And because it is such condescendingly low-hanging fruit I pretty much anticipated a resounding cheer from our black countrymen. What I did not expect was the bandwagon response amongst all other ethnicities. My continued surprise is derived from the fact that, as a whole, "Get Out" is simply not a very good film, let alone a good horror film. 
As a lifelong horror fan, I expect the unexpected; the "different" when it comes to highly anticipated "must-sees." There are multiple sub-genres of horror with no boundaries, making horror a somewhat easy category for up-and-coming directors to try something new and daring. Thus, it should have been even easier from someone with the industry ties Mr. Peele enjoyed prior to this debut to really stretch the limits of this malleable genre. Yet this film offered neither the new nor the daring. It was a bland, uncooked potato topped with a so-called plot-twist involving one of the single most overused suspense tropes aside from amnesia. Once this was revealed as the culprit, my eyes rolled so wildly I almost fell into the seat next to me. An already boring movie became not only incredibly corny, but almost intolerable from that moment forward. The "a-ha" moment is about as fresh as the breadcrumbs in the bottom of my toaster. 
Finally, I find it incredibly problematic that, as a half-white/half-black man, time and again Mr. Peele consistently falls to only one end of his family history. His identity seems almost consumed by his blackness. I often wonder how the white side of his family feels about his continued contempt, belittling, condemnation, and razzing of their heritage, their culture. We get it, Mr. Peele: you have black ancestry. But you also have just as much white ancestry. Why, then, this deep-seeded need for your repeated, almost labored, reassertion that blacks be at the forefront of your films when you have the ability to simply make films with "people" in them?
But if you must continue to make films with black main characters, whether for street-cred or because of some identity conflict, I only ask that you please write something more ground-breaking.

Long story short: this movie deserves all the praise it has. 'Get Out' was very highly recommended by a friend, also a fellow film enthusiast, and the subject matter of the film really interested me. Add to that a very promising trailer, the award nominations and wins and mostly positive word of mouth (even with the very vocal detractors), and interest was higher.

High expectations were not only met but also exceeded. Apologies for the cliché, but to me that is the best way to sum up my personal experience watching 'Get Out'. Can totally see why it was as well received as it was, though can also see why it has divided audiences on here. While it will never be one of my favourite films, 'Get Out' is among the better films of 2017 and does live up to the hype.

It's an incredibly well-made film visually, with stylish and unsettling cinematography and editing and some disturbingly surreal imagery that adds to, and enhances, the unease and sense of dread.

That the direction was done by a first-time director is a shock in itself, one of the most outstanding debut directing jobs seen in a long time by me. It's nostalgic in its embracing of contemporary and classic horror and also brave in the accomplished handling of the film's combative themes.

Being somebody who considers music important when talking about it, the music looms suitably ominously and fits well. 'Get Out' benefits from an extremely smart and clever script (though 'The Shape of Water' and especially 'Lady Bird' were worthier wins for the Best Original Screenplay Oscar in my view), that takes on a lot of elements and balances them adeptly and the individual elements handled very effectively.

Despite how it sounds, 'Get Out' struck me as more of a thriller with horror and comedic elements. It is highly successful on this front, with the thriller elements being taut, suspenseful and unsettling, the comedic ones being darkly funny and clever and the horror ones being imaginatively shocking and subtly uneasy. There is even some social commentary and interracial themes explored, and done thoughtfully and just about avoids preachiness while hitting hard still.

While all the performances are very fine, it is Daniel Kaluuya's superb lead performance that burns in the memory the most.

My only complaint of 'Get Out' is the too pat and somewhat silly ending that felt tacked on and like it came out of a different film, to me it too ended on a tonally jarring and that's it note.

Until then, the film was this close to being a masterpiece. So it was frustrating that it just missed out on that distinction. Nonetheless it's a great film that is among the year's better ones, brought down by an underwhelming ending. 9/10 Bethany Cox

This movie was exceptional. However, I do have some slight problems that cause it to lose a star for me. First, I felt like the slow build-up was not paid off. The trouble with this one is the racial stupidity which surrounds it. I've had to resist marking it down on that basis. It's listed on this site as the 2nd best horror film of all time - you've got to be kidding. The fact that it is, I suppose, afro-centric, should be neither here nor there. Even thinking of it in those terms is intrinsically racist - it's good because it's good, that's all that should matter. It isn't great - it's let down by its final act - & that's without the imbecilic alternate ending in which apparently, in the face of all, you know, readily available evidence, the police are just automatically going to arrest the black guy. Is that what happens? Really? Do you really think that's how justice works in the U.S.? Ironically, despite ridiculous tags like 'subversive', the film squibs on why black men (& woman) are the targets. Would have been a better film if it hadn't, then it might have been saying more than it actually does, but it still wouldn't have been subversive. That's infantile. The reality is that a lot of the people who are over the top about the import of this one are in effect patting the black guy on the head & telling him how clever he is. The actual film itself is irrelevant. If you look at the actual film though, rather than the colour of the skin of the person who made it - it's a high quality effort that I highly recommend, despite that fact that it runs out of ideas at the end & just settles on killing everybody. It is absolutely in the top 10-20 horror films of the 21st Century. It is not by any stretch of the imagination, the 2nd best horror film of all time.

Get Out is a rare and unique movie in this era when every movie apparently needs to be an action thriller or drama romance. It does what other movies are too scared to do which is to address race and makes it the focal point of the film. For some odd reason, Jordan Peele starts off the movie with an unnamed black character who is knocked out in the middle of the night and kidnapped by a person in a white car. Instead of the continuation of this scene, we are introduced to an African American photographer named Chris Washington and his Caucasian girlfriend Rose Armitage. We find out that the two of them are going to Rose's family since she wants to introduce them to Chris. Next, Chris asks Rose "does your family know I'm black" in which Rose hesitantly responds with "n-no". Jordan Peele ingeniously introduces two points of racial tension at the beginning of the film that makes the viewer bite at their nails with anticipation knowing full well that Chris will be facing exactly what he fears most at the Armitage house. We are then revealed to the white mother, father, and brother of the Armitage family and their two black employed servants. The juxtaposition of the races and roles of the Armitage family and their servants clearly convey the theme of racial inequality. Later, the Armitage host a party with mostly old white attendants and 1 black one. The white guests repeated uncomfortable praises of the black race and the weird behaviors of the only other 3 black people make both Chris and the viewer think that he is the odd one out. The consistent strange behaviors of the people at the party and Rose's indifference to this really generates the idea that something is seriously wrong. This feeling of unease hits its climax when 1 of the black guests has a nosebleed and yells at Chris to get out after a flash picture was taken of him. Overall, Get Out is a well-put-together movie that explores the fears of the African American population through an entertaining and gut-wrenching horror movie. The continuous rise of tension does a splendid job at symbolizing the fear that black people feel in a America that is at some times, unwelcoming to them. The contrast between race and job also does a good job at reflecting the economic inequalities faced in modern America. Now the movie is not free without its flaws. The action scenes don't seem realistic at all, especially not with that cheap and bright red CGI blood. Also, the existence of Rose's stack of photos feels like it was thrown in there to further the plot as there was no good reason given as to why Rose would have these photos and kept them in the place she did. Nevertheless, Jordan Peele's brilliant script and all of the actors' amazing acting really sell the pitch of Get Out. That the lives of black people in America can sometimes feel like something straight out of a horror movie.

Get Out is a very clever, smart and effective horror movie. The writing and directing are superb and manage to deliver a movie with some interesting racial undertones. Peele actually uses these undertones to complement the horror in this movie and try to work around the obvious cliches and stereotypes that are present from the very beginning. The acting supplements this beautifully by leaving no ambiguity regarding those stereotypes and cliches and creates really interesting characters and relationships and interactions between those characters. It also creates some genuinely really funny moments which are perfectly placed juxtapositions to the freakiness and unease that dominates so much of this movie. That is actually one of the things I like most about this movie; it's horror, but not in the conventional sense. This film doesn't rely on jump scares whatsoever and more focuses on being smart and crafting a really unique and interesting story. This movie has some really freaky and uncomfortable moments and interactions that give viewers so much unease and anxiety regarding what will happen next. Get Out has great intellectual and social horror within it and the acting gives that so much depth and makes it even freakier. The characters in the movie do some really smart stuff which is a testament to the writing and directing and helps some scenes to be really engaging and clever. The film flows very smoothly and there are no disruptive or awkward moments that hurt the quality of the scenes. It makes a lot of sense and doesn't rely on paranormal, supernatural or fantasy stuff to be unsettling or further along the plot, making this movie very different from other horror movies such as the Insidious and Conjuring franchises. Get Out is also an academic movie. If you're studying film in college, grad school or just as a career, you'll recognize concepts regarding spectatorship in some scenes of the movie. Thus, Get Out is capable of reaching audiences in a way a lot of other horror movies aren't and don't, making it truly unique as a work of art. It's not often that I can say that a horror flick is academic and contains college level concepts in it, and I'm thankful that I can do it with this one. The movie doesn't leave out the "ah-ha" moments of clarification, and makes them creative on their own by having certain things become clear and culminate. The end is nice and has a really funny moment in it that helps to perfectly wrap up the movie. Overall, Get Out is a fantastic movie and is a must-see for horror fans due to how unique and thought-provoking it is.

Jordan Peele's 2017 debut film as director, Get Out, is a modern horror masterpiece that plays on the reversal of racist horror tropes while also displaying contemporary covert racism to create a new type of horror film, one that bypasses gore and jump scares and embraces diversity, ultimately appealing to a modern audience that is far more open to conversations about race. 
The horror genre, which is rooted in literature and has since gained massive popularity through film and television, has a long history of deeply embedded racism. Black characters were often used in horror only as sacrificial lambs, sidekicks, and even supernatural beings alongside their white counterparts. Dick Halloran in The Shining, for instance, "shines" like Danny Torrance and yet is the only character to be killed in the film. It was extremely rare for Black characters in horror to make it to the end of the film and even rarer for them to be lead characters. Get Out completely reverses this trope by centering Black characters, allowing them to survive, and making them the heroes of the film. This fairly unprecedented creative choice in Get Out only heightens the film's cultural significance.
The true horrors of Get Out are the very realistic instances of covert and overt racism threaded into the film. Upon visiting his white girlfriend's family for the weekend, Chris Washington is repeatedly fetishized, stereotyped, and treated as an "other." It becomes increasingly clear throughout the film that Chris is an outsider. With this realization, Chris and the audience alike become increasingly uncomfortable. In horror, and American history as a whole, there are racist cultural conventions portraying Black people as villains and white people as victims. By reversing this trope, Peele offers audiences a new horror film experience -- one that speaks on modern racism in popular culture and appeals to the increased diversity that horror audiences crave. 
Between its uniqueness, its nods to horror legend The Shining, its incredible acting and visuals, and its very relevant commentary on race in America, Jordan Peele's Get Out is a must-see. The film does not shy away from addressing the realities of being Black in America, from covert microaggressions to an uneasy relationship with the police. Get Out is frightening not because of a monster under the bed, but rather the monster in bed with Chris. The horrors of racism are a reality and that is what makes the film so captivatingly horrific. A new cultural staple, you cannot call yourself a horror buff or pop culture aficionado without watching.

Even in just the title "Get Out" - the desire to escape is something I've often felt in situations where I am being discriminated against; I feel I want to escape from everyone around me, from everyone who is judging me and sizing me up, and this marvelous film captures that feeling very well.

Get Out Is The Debut Feature Film Brain Child Of Jordan Peele. W Movie Follows Chris, A Young African-American Photographer That Joins His Caucasian Girlfriend On A Weekend Visit To Her Parents' House. When Chris Begins To Notice Several Sketchy Things About The Family, He Begins To Question Their Intentions... It Isn't Often That A Filmmaker Can Solidify Their Spot In Hollywood With Their Debut Film, But "Get Out" Was Truly A Gem. The Crew Did Of Fantastic Job Of Bringing The Film To Life. The Music, Editing, WRITING, And Cinematography Were Absolutely Immaculate. The Cast Was Great Nonetheless, But Daniel Kaluuya And Allison Williams Stand Out In This Horror Flick. The Imagery And Symbolism Are Both Unsettlingly Eerie And Incredibly Beautiful. You Would Think That Peele Was A Seasoned Veteran In The Film Industry... "Get Out" Is A Masterpiece And No Film Review Or Film Critic Could Capture The Brilliance In Its Entirety In Just A Few Words. You HAVE To See It Before You Die. And With That Being Said, I'll Give Peele's Freshman Film A 95%.

Get Out explores racism in a completely unexpected way, and will have you saying "wait, what the f*ck is happening?".
Although it's the white folks who are the monsters, it's actually the black characters - the victims - who provide the creeps.
Although a film such as this was rather timely, with race relations and identity politics playing an increasingly common role in (particularly American) society, I do feel it represents an older style of racism in which black people were considered not just property, but status goods to show off to your friends. Or, maybe, it does sum up modern racism perfectly, and - sorry! - a lot of "woke" culture: white people pretending to love black people, but really just exploiting them for a personal agenda.

Jordan Peele's 2011 Get Out is a masterful haunting movie that destructs racism in a haunting way. This film centers around the character Chris who travels to spend the weekend with his girlfriend and her parents. Unlike other film makers within this genre, this film leads to a truly shocking end, leading audience members to make their own horrifying conclusions. Unlike some of Peele's other work, such as Toy Story 4 and Storks, Get Out brings some important social commentary to light in an extremely disturbing way. Nevertheless, this film also keeps this distressing topic wrapped under a thin layer of humor that allows the audience to relax before realizing the extent of what is happening. All Would you describe that propaganda as mostly divisive or mostly exploitative? Is it a mix? Is it primarily something else? Describe an example. What is your critical reaction to propaganda? All in all, I would give this film 5 stars! Not only does it address some important issues, but it leads the audience astray, making them believe that the film is going to be wrapped up in a particular manor. It addresses the complete misunderstanding and underlying racism within today's culture while also attacking the selfishness and ignorance of those who are not affected by this. One of the most alluring things about this film is the cinematography. The use of the lighter and brighter colorization of the family members as well as the fashion that is used to depict the characters is incredible. Not to mention the contrast of white against the blood as well as the astounding acting done by each character. Furthermore, the storyline is extremely well done and quite misleading. Much like films of a similar genre it leaves the audience gasping and shaking at the end. All in all, Get Out is an incredible film that addresses and deconstructs racism in a horrifying and haunting way. Both memorable and entertaining, I would highly recommend.

The acting is so well done that I actually felt trapped at a party, and I didn't even get the benefit of refreshments!  Ugh.  Watching people talk is not what I want in a movie.  Usually, when there is that many uninteresting people in a movie, I at least get an appearance by Godzilla or some other fantastic thing.  A minor spoiler: Godzilla does not make any appearances in this movie.  There aren't any Marvel Studios level special effects or spectacularness.  So, this really wasn't my kind of movie.  
      For the story that was told, the actors and actresses did a really fine job.  The movie has a plot, and it takes a while to unfold.  If you're looking for escapism when you watch a movie, this may not be for you.  If you don't get enough real life in your life and you need to supplement it with your movies, then this flick may be for you.

Get Out is quite frankly one of the most unique films made in years. The reasons it's critic scores are so high is for that reason. Jordan Peele was revolutionary with his story telling and it was a breath of fresh air to the horror genre. Well it's not exactly a horror film as it could fit under a ton of different genres. The story really brings up a lot of questions about race and the thought that white people stereotype black people in certain ways. It touches on a number of those points throughout and non is more apparent than when Chris is pulled over in his car. He's not even driving and the police officer assumes he's to blame. The amount of incidents in America and around the world which are similar to this are in the media often. Peele really highlights for us the plight that some black people are going through still to this day.

It's a star making turn for Peele as a director. His follow up film Us was also a incredible movie and he has the Candyman remake coming out later in the year (hopefully) which also looks very good. The uniqueness of his script really made a change in Hollywood. We are usually bogged down with sequels and remakes but he gave us a fresh story and type of film that audiences and critics both loved. 

The cast are excellent. Like I said Kaluuya is reaping the rewards of this film with big roles since and he will continue to get more and more. The star of this film though is Rob. It takes the timing of an actual comedian like Peele to really pull off the horror-comedy; the former is relatively easy, the latter is where writers in the genre typically run into trouble, and the threads binding them are often jagged and noticeable. Here, that isn't the case, especially given that scenes associated with both are clearly designed to serve a unified commentary on race relations. Creepy without resorting to jumpscares or similar cop-outs (opting for the spine-tingle rather than the scream in most instances), and the diverse range of interactions demonstrating the discomfort associated with actually discussing race openly are sincere and well-done. Furthermore, it's not just narrative; the cinematography associated with "the Sunken Place" was wholly unexpected and engrossing. One of the most genuine and sincere aspects of this film: only psychopaths use Bing. (4.5/5)

To say "Get Out" breathes a new breath of life into the horror genre (true) diminishes its stature as probably the best new film since "Birdman." This comes down to brilliant directing of a fresh, twisted script, fascinating character composition and  spot-on casting of a troupe born for these roles. Daniel Kaluuya, is amazing as the savvy, yet vulnerable, Chris, tricked by psycho-black magic. Allison Williams, his adorable, but menacing, girlfriend and Katherine Keener, her earthy, yet, evil mother are incredible and incredibly horrific. Yet I have mixed feelings after watching this movie a second time. The basic premise is powerful, that white folks saw, and often still see, black folks in limited capacities, i.e. athletes, sex toys, objects to control. Still, the film takes some huge risks that don't always pay off. Though Peele himself is a comic genius in Key & Peele episodes, the comedy here feels like adding Red Skelton to "Psycho." More troubling, "Get Out" seeks to lambaste white folks for stereotyping and abusing black folks (all too true) while stereotyping all white folks in the movie as the modern equivalent of evil slave owners. Conversely, most of the black characters are portrayed as mere victims of white oppression. Of course, the film isn't meant to be realistic, anymore than "Stepford Wives" (1975). They both operate as effective parables, while taking us on a screaming fun ride.

The movie Get Out is already a highly-acclaimed movie because of its writing and its ability to make light – for better or for worse – of racism in the United States. Although the screenwriting and the themes are great, there are many more complexities that go into the making of this movie that sets it apart from other dark comedy and horror movies. These specifications include the profundity of the message, the play on colors, and the intertextuality with other horror films.
	The movie has very clear stance in terms of ideology and ethics – anti-racism. By putting a spotlight on the micro narratives that are encompassed within racist America, albeit an exaggerated one, the movie is shedding light on the struggles of African-Americans. One of the ways Jordan Peele challenges the status quo is by showing a Black person in both ends of the spectrum – inexplicable hate and inexplicable fetishization. The fetishization and exoticization in the movie shows a new take on traditional racism in movies because it's a different type of racism that still produces the result of otherizing and antagonizing Black people. The ending, in my opinion, helps solidify the message because as we see a cop car approaching, Chris is ironically seen to give up with the knowledge that, for a Black man, he will be blamed for any and all crime. The fact that the policeman is not only a Black man but Chris's friend is a direct challenge to the Status Quo of white America.
	What is a movie about race if not another commentary on socialized colors? This is what Get Out establishes subconsciously to the viewers of the movie. Throughout, everything that has to do with Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) is blue – his shirt, his memories, his cop friend's uniform are all shades of blue. In contrast, his girlfriend's Rose (Allison Williams), in direct contrast, has red and orange hues – her shirt, her car, and her house all have similar hues. This was very intentional to not only show the contrast between the characters but to signify the roles of the character. For one, not only is red associated with mystery and secret societies, but red and orange hues are known as warm colors; this overwhelming use of warmth takes away its authenticity and with Rose's mother being a hypnotherapist, she was probably well aware of the atmosphere to create.	
Jordan Peele has gone to reveal all the different references that Get Out has with other horror movies most significant of them is The Shining directed by Stanley Kubrick. This intertextuality with other horror films provides the movie with a self-reflexive and meta-reflexive aspect. The movie establishes the self-reflexive nature early on in the movie when Chris's friend communicates his suspicions about a Black man going to visit his white girlfriend's house. This clearly ascertains the movie as one about race. The meta-reflexivity on horror movies is rather subtle such as when Chris is given a house tour as a reference to The Overlook Hotel in The Shining. This demonstrates how the movie is aware of its status as a horror movie and is also aware of how horror movies are meant to act with its shot patterns and cinematography.

Jordan Peele's "Get Out" is a funny, scary and timely horror film about race relations in America. With his directorial debut, writer/director Jordan Peele has crafted a disturbing satire on racism. It's not easy to infuse social commentary into a horror movie, but Peele pulls it off seamlessly. Using a sharp screenplay and excellent ensemble cast, Peele crafts a magnificent first feature that showcases his talents as a filmmaker. Peele's screenplay is superb and arguably the main highlight of the movie. Filled with colorful characters, witty dialogue and hilarious situations, the script elevates the film to another level. In terms of acting, the entire cast is at the top of its game. Daniel Kaluuya delivers a dazzling performance as an African-American man caught in a horrific situation. With riveting expressions, he captures the terror of being a victim of racism. Although "Get Out" is hauntingly effective, ultimately it is not a flawless horror film. It starts off with an intriguing premise, but loses steam towards the end. Peele goes a little overboard with the ending. Peele's decision to end the movie with a bload-soaked finale is bold and innovative, but it doesn't entirely work. Nevertheless, fans of horror films will definitely enjoy "Get Out" and so will movie-goers seeking a timely message. At a time when racism is rarely depicted in horror films, it's reassuring to be reminded that movies like "Get Out" are still getting made.

My enjoyment for this movie was heightened more by recognizing some of the white actors in the movie as some of my favorites, and even moreso than other movies by having read the Wiki and IMDb trivias beforehand. This was shockingly well done - I saw Us first before going back to watch this movie and wasn't expecting something so excellent as a result. The performances were uniformly fantastic. I only begrudgingly appreciate movies by Blumhouse as I'm not generally convinced that extremely low budgets do anything to make better movies, just better profit margins, but in several of their movies they've surprised me, this included. The music was also very well done, an interesting thing since it was the composer's very first movie credit.

Jordan Peele's directorial debut is a masterclass in craftsmanship.  Everything is so meticulously designed around its central theme that this movie would feel right at home sitting on a shelf next to the best of Hitchcock.

Film Review: Get Out
Introduction
The Get Out movie is good because feels fresh and rare in a way that studio horror movies almost never do. The movie however, doesn't feels no such obligations manners. A movie of horror about a black guy (Daniel Kaluuya) trying to survive his first weekend with his white girlfriend's (Allison Williams) family, it's locked in the present, he feels uncomfortable because he is the only black guy in the house and the family of her girlfriend act weird in front of him.
Summary of the movie
Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) and his girlfriend Rose (Allison Williams), they are preparing to go home to meet her parents doing the luggage. Rose hasn't told them he's black, and Chris get a little angry because is going to me akward which she blows off as no big deal, but he's wary. His TSA Agent buddy (LilRel Howery) warns him against going too and tell him is to soon because they are only 4 months together, but Chris is falling in love with Rose.
On the way to the house of rose's parents on the road they are talking and they are running through a deer and it damages a little the car of Rose, Chris goes down to see the damage and what went through and sees that the focus of the car of the front part broke and the rearview mirror broke and he hears noises from the animal that went through and goes to see him and was dead and if it was a deer they call the police by Rose and the policeman tells him that he should have called Animal control and the policeman asks Rose for her identification and gives it to and, then turns to see Chris who is sitting in the car and asks for identification to the same and was not driving and Rose tells the police that because if the He was not driving and the policeman tells him that this is the protocol and tells him that no and Chris is giving him the identification and Rose says no and the policeman decides not to give it to him and leaves and Rose tells him that he should not be like that and they get into the car and Chris thanks rose for defending him.
Chris and Rose arrive at her parents' house, something is unsettling. Sure, Dean (Bradley Whitford) and Missy (Catherine Keener) seem friendly enough, but almost too much so, like they're looking to impress Chris. More unnerving is the demeanor of a groundskeeper named Walter (Marcus Henderson) and a housekeeper named Georgina (Betty Gabriel), There's just something wrong. But, as we so often do in social or racial situations, Chris keeps trying to excuse their behavior maybe Walter is jealous and maybe Georgina has an issue with Chris being with a white woman. The lurking presence of Rose's odd brother (Caleb Landry Jones), doesn't help. 
Chris go out to have a smoke one night, and, well, things start to get even stranger in ways I won't spoilin fact, the preview gives away way too much. Avoid it if you can.

Jordan Peele absolutely kills it in his big directorial debut. Daniel Kaluuya (Kick-Ass 2, Black Panther) is a wonderful casting choice and acts the role of Chris Washington perfectly. I didn't initially recognize anyone else besides Catherine Keener, but thought the casting was consistently good for every character. All the scenes sell their intended emotions. The creepy and unsettling moments build great tension and suspense. You are constantly asking questions you want answers to, which keeps you constantly engaged in the scene. The movies core deals with race relations between white people and African Americans. It shows how some African American people still deal with residual racism, and how uncomfortable it can be to meet your girlfriends parents. It also heavily plays on white peoples cultural appropriation of African American's in modern society. The third act twist is satisfying and well written. With all the terrible horror movies that have come out in the last decade, Get Out was a much needed breath of fresh air.

The horror genre has often been used to comment on social issues what with The Beguiled (1971) serving as a statement on the result of the oppression of women but this film has been acclaimed as the socially conscious film of our times. I personally didn't see the film as being quite as clever or entertaining as many have claimed it is but it still had some merits and was better than the average horror film. No, this was not one of the best films of 2017 by any means, Love After Love (2017), The Florida Project (2017) and The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017) were better, and I wanted so desperately to like it more than I did.

Young African-American photographer Chris, Daniel Kaluuya, is concerned about meeting the parents of his wealthy, white girlfriend Rose Armitage, Allison Williams, because he believes they might be racist. When he meets them he is unsettled by their subtle racism as they make offensive comments but are never actively hostile. He is hypnotized by matriarch, Missy, Catherine Keener, while having his fears about the docile African-American servants at the house assuaged by Armitage's overbearing father Dean, Bradley Whitford. Chris tries to keep in contact with his friends as he witnesses increasingly suspicious actions and realizes that the Armitages may be using him for their own purposes. Armitage tries to subdue him but after a dramatic dinner party he becomes obsessed with getting away from the family and revelations about his girlfriend's romantic history cause him to believe that he is one of her many targets in a giant plot.

The most effective sequences in the film come when Whitford and Keener deliver chillingly unaware monologues about how they "Voted for Obama" or admire the athletes who delivered a Black Power salute at the 1968 Olympics. There is a strange envy in their voices as it is almost as though they have the desire to be persecuted and through the eyes of our protagonist, who has faced persecution in his life, this is something to fear. When an intensely creepy Caleb Landry Jones, as Armitage's wild brother Jeremy, leers at Chris and questions him aggressively as to why he has not pursued a career in athletics the tension ramps up and understand the small but deadly slights that African-Americans have to face almost every day. Peele's screenplay tackles this issue efficiently and effectively as he does not belabor the point and Whitford and Keener's disarming deliver is so smooth that it knocks you off balance.

Keener is the one who really steals the whole picture as the tight smiles and passive aggressive comments she dishes off in almost every scene are delightfully insincere. While Keener has the power to be charismatic her best performances have required her to play uptight, angry women who express their internal range through chipping away at others. Whitford is decent as he spends his time trying to prove just how liberal and socially progressive he is but Keener is truly villainous with her masterful hypnotism of her prey and utter lack of remorse coming off as terrifying. Of all of the performances in this film Keener would have been most deserving of an Academy Award nomination. Instead Kaluuya who is fine but relatively forgettable received the recognition in a lineup that could have included Casey Affleck in A Ghost Story (2017) and Harris Dickinson in Beach Rats (2017).

The movie got far too self-important when reviews made it seem as though it was making a political statement on the level of No End (1985) or Short Working Day (1981). The film isn't an incredible political satire as while it makes it's points well it does become a dumb horror film in it's third act and while the scares are decent they are not on the level of Suspiria (1977) or The Shining (1980). Horror films are not my favorite as while I can appreciate the fact that films like Carrie (1976) and Psycho (1960) are exceptionally good I do not see this film as being on that level and as a comedy and a political statement it is not quite good enough. I have many friends who love the film and see it as being exciting and informative but I happen to not be in that camp.

If there is one thing I admired, it was the comic relief character. If you have seen this movie, you know who I mean. Sorry that I cannot remember his name. I would say this movie would deserve a 50% score if I were being generous, and I have no idea why I would be generous.

Being different always have two ways to go, either it will be easily accepted in the audience or thrashed severely by the same people. It took the risk and fortunately, it worked out! Jordan Peele has done an impressive job with the screenplay and presentation of the story. The clever use of passive racism and well written dialogues did their work ; they made the story engaging in the buildup phase. The sound score and the edits were brilliantly done. All of the technical aspects created An eeriness that gradually keeps you on the edge the whole time. Performances as usual were magnificent (Especially from the Lead actor Daniel Kaluuya). The brutality and the gore in the climax fulfilled the story. It makes your heart racing! Now you must be wondering if I'm praising this film that much ; then why I'm giving this a 7/10? There are some reasons for that! The Rod Williams character annoyed me the most, I don't understand the need of adding unnecessary comic scenes or humours into these kind of movies which are supposed to be serious and scary throughout ! Well I'm not going to spoil the main concept but it felt Poorly explained and illogical in a sense! The story could have easily elaborated all the facts in much more clearer fashion! The Director wanted to put all of our attention to the main character of Chris ; and in order to achieve that he somehow neglected the other major character buildups! Those were needed in my opinion. Overall a Technically sound movie that delivers on the main subject of Racism culture and at the same time makes you uneasy and scared but in no way it's a flawless film.

Mind-bogglingly original, Get Out is an extremely fresh and engaging experience that will keep you thinking about it long after the credits roll. What was in particular an extremely smart decision by Peele was his decision to make Rose evil (and subvert the white savior trope), which makes you rethink and view everything before in such a hauntingly different way. That of course can also be attributed to Allison Williams' performance (I will never forget how she so seamlessly transitions into evil mode), while the rest of the ensemble also all do great jobs (especially Daniel Kaluuya who was great but maybe not Oscar-worthy, and Betty Gabriel who really did something crazy with her performance). Unfortunately, though, while I loved the very strong mystery horror side of this film, I was not a fan of the comedy (which provided too much tonal inconsistency) and thought that as a whole, the strong narrative and symbolic imagery was never matched by strong enough racial commentary. This is unlike Peele's second film Us, where the latter seems to be stronger. Overall, however, Peele still does a very much Oscar-worthy job where his vision is thoroughly focused and used to craft a thrilling film. (which is even more impressive considering this is his directorial debut)

"Get Out" is brilliant and surprising if so also the kind of racial discrimination he talks about. In most films so far, they have focused on an approach that sees white as the top race. Here, by contrast, they deal with something much more complex: the so-called "positive racism." That is to say, whites who go out of their way to clarify how black is the new white from their point of view, but in truth, they have no basic respect for blacks as individuals and not as an idea, and hence the deadly and destructive violence as described here.
"Get Out" is, in the end, a horror classics that will not be forgotten soon, and in the future will be further influenced by its contents and messages. Of course, he will deal with the young Palestinian who is going to meet his girlfriend's parents for the first time, Meretz voters who live in Ramat Aviv Gimmel and proudly tell him that they have just finished reading "Yakubian House" "And from now on it is already clear how it will end.

Decent movie that was way overhyped due to the socio-political climate at the time it was released. Maybe if I hadn't seen The Skeleton Key months before and guessed the plot 10 minutes in I might have enjoyed it more, but really if you take away the racial commentary of the movie it's just a solid horror, not the 98% "best horror ever" it's treated as.  

The other element that Get Out relies on is the idea that white people want to "be us," which, although a nice fantasy, seems to be entirely untrue; I have yet to meet a white person that would trade places with a black person for any amount of money, much less to pursue this as a goal. 

Watch for the acting and competent direction, but the emphasis on the completely unoriginal script that went on to (ironically) win Original Screenplay is just a thinly veiled ripoff.

I won't go into spoilers, but this movie raises a lot of interesting questions. Can something be racist and not racist at the same time? What the villain(s) do of course is horrible, but their reasoning, though still morally wrong, can be interpreted as both racist and not racist at the same time! You can argue that them going after black people specifically is racist, but another person can argue that it's in a weird way, admiring black people... just in the most evil way possible.

Get Out is a very good movie. It has great surprises, acting, writing, perfectly balanced humor, but above all, it delivers a gut-punching message that is very important to todayï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s social and political climate. There is even an alternate ending that will leave you with a lasting pang of guilt that will force you to examine the very threads of this world, and more specifically your world. First off, one of the awesome things about this film is, in fact, the camera work. Jordan Peele did a great job of shooting each scene, in a way that made the horror scenes seem scarier, like how the camera was closer and shakier. Another great thing was acting. For instance, Allison Williams, who played the innocent girlfriend, and transitioned with ease to then play a horror villain who seduces black people to eventually transfuse them with other people's consciousness. Also, Catherine Keener and Bradley Whitford, who play "woke" parents who struggle to accept the interracial relationship, and then transition to playing a demented psychiatrist and neurosurgeon respectively. And then there is Caleb Landry Jones, who has a stellar performance of the drunk, dark, and brooding brother in the background. 
Another thing that makes this movie so superb is it's writing. First about this, is the basic plot. The way that the movie starts off so innocently, but weaves itself into being just terrifying. With the subtle, but very creepy Andre, to Missy and her wacky and just plain scary therapy sessions. Then at the end, the surgery which detaches scalps and shows brains, to people getting stabbed with a taxidermied moose, kicked in the head, choked, stabbed with a fork, and shot with a gun. Then there is also the other aspect of the film, which is what makes it so great. Jordan Peele wrote the film with his parts of his Key and Peele experience, and it was also very funny. Most of the jokes, however, required bad language, but it paid off. There weren't too many jokes, but the amount of them was great and hit a perfect balance with the rest of the seriousness of the movie. Then there is the message. The villain of the movie might appear to be the Armitage's, but the real horror is systemic racism. The alternate ending also conveys this message. It shows how the system, the racially biased system, always favors the majority. It also shows how one can beat there own demons and feel at peace with themselves, even in the midst of all life's craziness. However, there are the downsides, like how the characters don't have clear arcs and the film is quite jump-scarey, but the movie is really just plain great.

The most dazzlingly original and purposely provocative American dramatic film of 2017, Jordan Peele’s critical and commercial smash started the year off with a startling bang by cross-wiring two normally distinct genres: horror and social satire. A question to ask friends: at what point does the movie shift decisively from satire to horror? That there’s no clear, obvious answer is a tribute to Peele’s ingenuity and skill in blending the two. The film is beautifully directed, with a nuanced color palette and expressively fluid camerawork. When the shift into horror does arrive, the movie’s art-film look makes it all the more seductive and powerful. And the nightmarish visions that occupy the tale’s final act couldn’t be more purposeful. If the satiric sections suggest a superficial gloss on current racial relations, the darker elements take us much deeper, all the way back to the brutalities of slavery that still undergird American experience. There could hardly be a better to movie to begin the year when America’s first black president was replaced by one who appeals to white supremacists, further proof that history is anything but a continuous forward march.

The movie itself is not that good when it comes to story telling. There are some ridiculous plot holes. For example, when Rose and Chris are travelling to the Armitage estate and the deer flies past their car, why does Rose call the cops if she's into the plan of kidnapping Chris? Doesn't that just leave a trail for Rod to find Chris when he's out to search Chris. 

Speaking of Rod, Chris tells Rod to take care of his dog, and Rose has NO ISSUES WITH IT? Is this even a kidnapping at this point? Why not just force Chris to take the dog along? Why let him tell Rod to take care of the dog and telling him he was headed to Rose's parents? This in particular is the only reason Rod is able to figure out a lot of the "mystery" around the Armitages, which shows some of the weaknesses of the story.

These are only some of the plot holes in the movie, and there is a LONG LIST of them. The story is not very tight.

Acting-wise, there were some really good moments that I personally found enjoyable as they added to the storyline. For example, when the couple is travelling to the estate, Rose snatches away Chris' cigarette and throws it out. This is good. It is later carried onto when the Armitages point out Chris' natural tick when he's craving a smoke. It's natural progression and it works. Another example would be when the dad rants about deers. This could be translated as him being on his nerves while talking to Chris, and it comes off well. 

Message-wise:
1) Racism is still very prevalent in the US
2) Liberal elites (white people especially) have some weird fetish for black people.

I think the message is pretty strong, and is worth the mention. Peele did capture SOME of it, like when the whole party is treating Chris like a big star, and unnaturally attracted to him (the lady asking about the sex [Mask it in subtlety and anything is fair game]), and where the white fellas are all awkward around Chris. The message does get sent, but not to a great extent. And I'm fairly certain it's due to the mediocre story-writing. Message is important, but not as much as the story telling.

A decent movie, relatively entertaining, but essentially a thriller-by-the-numbers with a little (and i do mean only a little) comedy thrown in. It has a great (but unoriginal) premise and good acting all around, but the thrills are lacklustre and the suspense is thin.
It is also important to note that all the subtext other reviewers have mentioned regarding race is very America-centric, and will likely be lost on international viewers. I believe that being unable to fully understand and appreciate this subtext was the main reason I was left feeling like this was just a good movie, rather than an excellent one.

Former Key and Peele star, Jordan Peeleï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s Get Out is more than just a horror. The story of a black manï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s visit to his girlfriendï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s house gone wrong is saturated in absurdist satire that captures something in the zeitgeist. This movie has notable marks of previous horror movies making it a descendant of two other classic horror movies, 1968ï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s Rosemaryï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s Baby and especially 1975ï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s Stepford Wives. Where as those films used frightening analogies for womenï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s issues, Get Out, uses the same structure to capture todayï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s racial climate. Get Out, is littered with symbolism having to do with slavery and the old south as well as capturing Peeleï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s more overt theme of racial horror. In an interview, Peele described this movie as one that reflects real fears of his and real issues that heï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s dealt with in the past. The build-up of malevolence in the house, the suspense and odd behavior and twist at the end of the film make Jordan Peeleï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s Get Out, one for the ages. Although it deviates as a horror film by implicating many sub genres, Get Outï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s true horror lies with the real-life implications it hiddenly conveys through the use of eyes, animals and even cameras. Throughout the film, director Jordan Peele uses the sense of sight to amplify imbalances of power and control often drawn along racial lines. 
Itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s notable to say that the symbolism of eyes and cameras is a crucial part of the film since even before we see Chris (the main character) we are introduced to him through his art. The audience is shown black-and-white prints of his work on the walls of his Brooklyn apartment in a sequence set to Childish Gambinoï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s ï¿ 1/2 1/2Red Boneï¿ 1/2 1/2?. It is established at the beginning that Chris through his profession is a trained observer. Constantly around his neck, his camera functions as a protective shield of sorts between the odd behavior he encounters, especially from the familyï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s large group of white friends and neighbors and two black servants, Georgina and Walter. Chrisï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) camera is also a means to observe and escape. Itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s through his lens that Chris spots another black person at the Armitagesï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) gatherings. It is obvious to see that the man that Chris spots when he goes up to him and introduces himself to is not himself. Logan as he introduces himself to Chris has a glossy look and a far-off stare, which Chris makes note of . When Chris takes a picture of Logan to send to a friend the flash goes off and a bizarre transformation takes place. Loganï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s face turns that of happy to that of fear. With blood coming from his nose he launches himself at Chris screaming, ï¿ 1/2 1/2Get Out!ï¿ 1/2 1/2?, which seems like an act of aggression but Chris senses itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s something else. This scene evokes multiple motifs of the importance of cameras and phones for many African-Americans experiencing police brutality, especially in light of an earlier scene where Chris is asked to show I.D when he wasnï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t the one driving. It is no coincidence that photographic evidence later provides Chris with his biggest clues as he tries to uncover the secrets of the Armitagesï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM). Somewhat plainly, Get Out, suggests that cameras have the power to reveal. 
As stated before, Get Out, is loaded with symbolism of slavery and the old south, with the plantation like estate of the Armitagesï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) and some older looking costumes of Georgina. These visuals echo that or past is forever interwoven into our present. The first time of something wrong occurs when the deer crashes into the car. The moaning deer is linked to Chris and is an omen of what is to come for him. As Nick(classmate) pointed out, in one frame the front of the car is seen post deer accident and the only bloody side is the passenger side, the side Chris is sitting in. Chris is viewed as the innocent sacrifice just like the deer and in the final act, when Chris is strapped to the chair he looks up and sees the deer head on the wall, symbolism for what the family wants to do to him, make him a dead trophy. 
Chrisï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM) escape is by no means a happy ever after type story, when Rodd comes to save Chris, he serves as the comic Deus Ex Machina. Here, the comedy, hope and relief save the story from the defeats that conclude Stepford Wives and Rosemaryï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s Baby yet there is still a lurking threat skulking beyond the grounds of the Armitage home at the end of Get Out. What resonates with many and underscores the happy ending notions that underneath our progress, there is, under the surface, that lingering prejudice and antagonism. After the film concludes, it makes us ponder the thought that we might learn to be a little less naÃ¯ve, a little more cautiously paranoid and open our eyes to how potently our history still informs our present. As the saying goes, history tends to repeat itself time and time again.

How will you weave a story full of morals and social issues into a movie? A debuting director, Jordan Peele, had to ask himself that question. Heâ(TM)s the extraordinaire who directed the captivating film, Get Out. The horror film may be one of 2017â(TM)s best movies, if not the best. It touches on issues revolving the past and the society that we all know today. Peele gives his audience the opportunity to dive into a world full of wonders and mysteries, leaving them off of the edge of their seats. 
As a black man, Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya), is faced with prejudice throughout the movie as he dates his white girlfriend, Rose Armitage (Allison Williams). As the plot thickens, he decides to visit his girlfriendâ(TM)s family for some time. Chris uncovers secretive things as he learns more about her family -- things that he wished he didnâ(TM)t know. When Chris arrived at the house with Rose, they are introduced by her mother, Missy Armitage (Catherine Keener), and father, Dean Armitage (Bradley Whitford). After spending some time there, he realizes that something was strange. He finds out that Roseâ(TM)s mother brainwashes people and her father perform extreme neurological procedures. Chris has to survive through these insane moments and âget outâ? of the house to be freed from Roseâ(TM)s family and their craziness. 
A plot like this is one of the many reasons why Get Out got so many good critics, including mine. This movie is no other. It isnâ(TM)t just some boring, shabby movie that is clichÃ (C) -- itâ(TM)s a masterpiece. It has many hidden hints and âeaster eggsâ? that contributes to the overall message. For example, when the couple were on the way to Roseâ(TM)s house, they accidently hit a deer on the road. They watched the deer gradually die as they resettle. (***SPOILER ALERT) When Chris got brainwashed by Missy Armitage, he was sent to a room that had him strapped to a chair. At that moment, he finds a head of a deer on the wall directly in front of him. This represents how after he watched the deer die, the deer came back to watch him die. Furthermore, the horror behind it screams excitement to my ears. I love how they sneak little creepy moments throughout the movie while not just implementing them to make it just scary. The director takes the subject of race and transform it into an entertaining work of art that attracts many watchers across the globe. This movie is mostly for young adults and mature teenagers, but if youâ(TM)re up for the challenge, then go for it! 5/5 Stars

Holy jeezums, Get Out is fantastic! I was expecting to like it and get a fun horror movie, but I wasn't expecting a horror movie on par with The Shining.

What the villain(s) do is undeniably ungodly, but is it even racist? I won't go into spoilers, but this movie raises a lot of interesting questions. Can something be racist and not racist at the same time? 

What the villain(s) do of course is horrible, but their reasoning, though still morally wrong, can be interpreted as both racist and not racist at the same time! You can argue that them going after black people specifically is racist, but another person can argue that it's in a weird way, admiring black people... just in the most evil way possible.

Get Out messes with my head, and it is very very clever with how everything is set up and resolved.

'Get Out' really is well-written and directed, managing to make a horror/thriller out of an already hideous situation - meeting your SO's parents for the first time - whilst adding an intriguing mystery and timely commentary on racism. What's so clever, though, is that it doesn't go about it in any way that you might expect, keeping things mysterious with an increasingly bizarre atmosphere, until the fantastic and surprising crescendo of a final act. The characters are brilliantly played by a talented cast (Kaluuya is superb) and the dialogue hones in on how alienating people can be (whether they mean to or not) when talking to someone of colour. Of course, Peele being Peele, you might expect at least some humour there; fear not, there is a bit of that, too. Overall, it's just a really smart and entertaining film that, at the same time, manages to "air the dirty laundry", so to speak, and forces people to think about stereotypes, prejudice, racism and how we interact with one another in general. Bringing that together in such an enjoyable way is no easy feat.
