"If you're in an interracial relationship you'd better what out! You can't trust your white partner, they're all murderers!" is what I got from this movie.

If this was supposed to be horror "comedy" there was nothing funny to be found, just plot holes and nonsensical logic that does not hold up to the slightest bit of scrutiny. The gardener and maid are actually the white grandparents! Ok, so why are they treated so poorly? Do they want Chris to know they're racist? I thought the whole point was to keep that sh*t hidden?
They have to hypnotize people so they can "sedate" them to do the surgery! Ok so why doesn't the mother just work as a therapist in the city, gain clients' trust, then hypnotize them to come out to the house? Why add in all this uncomfortable stuff about interracial relationships being "dangerous" and "you can't trust white b*tches lol" when you could just have the mom hypnotizing people from the start? 

As someone who is in an interracial relationship, I am well aware of the stigma still behind interracial couples a lot of the time, and while the start of the movie would lead you to believe it is going to show a good, positive view of an interracial couple, it quickly becomes apparent that this is just as prejudiced against people like me as the white people the movie protrays.

And then there's this movie's weird love of the TSA. I'm sure there are some good people working in the TSA, don't get me wrong, but implying the TSA are basically like cops (the character in the TSA, Rod, even drives a cop car at the end inexplicably) is just confused and does not have nearly as much humor as they want it to.

And then there was the uncomfortable fact that there was a Japanese man bidding on Chris' body with all the white people as if they were saying "the Japanese are just as bad as white people!" which plays into the whole model minority dynamic and ignores the fact that--shockingly--Asians face racism too!

The one good thing this movie had going for it was the acting, which was all fantastic! The rest is a mess of sloppy implications and a nonsense plot that fails on every level.

When I first saw the trailer for this film, I wasn't really interested. I am not a huge fan of horror movies, and this one didn't look special to me. Then I heard the positive buzz, and was intrigued. Leaning it was more about racism than jump scares changed my perspective some, but I still expected to like it less than most. 

I was wrong.

There are certainly horror elements, but the scares supplement the story; they aren't just there to make you jump. Speaking of story - it is incredibly rich and deep, again using the twists as turns as a medium for the movie's vast social commentary. 

This also seems like one that might be just as good or better with a second viewing, as there is so much symbolism and subtext early in the film that you may have glossed over because you hadn't yet seen the rest of the film. 

I still don't love horror movies, but if Jordan Peele keeps making them, I'll keep watching them.
Lots of fun mocking the 'progressive' crowd, who are usually the biggest racists of all, combined with a thrilling story.

The movie "Get Out" is a revolution in what it brings to the big screen and it sets a precedent for not only future horror films, but for all of black cinema. The purpose of the movie was to show how racism is still alive in today's world, even though it is not as extreme as it was back when slavery was around. However, the movie still manages to keep the audience engaged in a horror-thriller.The movie does a good job in not only capturing the social aspect of being a minority in this country, but it keeps the movie entertaining with a different spin on horror. The idea of a social setting being the antagonist puts a new way to insight fearThe movie "Get Out" should be considered one of the most thought-provoking horror films of all time and it should be discussed for years to come. Not only is it a great horror film, it sets a high standard for black cinema going forward.It is a one-of-a-kind movie that opened the door to many conversations about culture and perspective.
An explosive ending makes up for an extremely slow build.  Not really the horror film it was marketed as - more of a thriller.

But a second viewing will unearth many nuanced details scattered through-out.  Fortunately, debut director Jordan Peel adeptly shows more than tells and avoids ever being dull.  The film holds a poignant mirror to society's many racial issues, leaving audiences with plenty to talk about post credits.  Must watch.

It has been very difficult to find a horror film in the 21st century that even surpasses 3 stars. However, Jordan Peele's Get Out brought back everything that was good about a classic horror film and combined it with the modern production quality needed to make a brilliant movie. While there were a few jump scares along the way, it seemed like Get Out mostly relied on plot, visuals, and score to scare the audience. The acting was phenomenal and while it was clear that Peele was trying to get some social commentary across in his film, it was subtle so it didn't come off as propaganda. I'd consider this movie a must-see for horror fans.

"The Mind is a terrible thing to waste". The idea of a comedy star writing and directing a horror film was strange to me, but Jordan Peele broke my expectations. This film was excellent. The best film of 2017!! The plot is simply this "Chris and his girlfriend Rose go upstate to visit her parent's for the weekend. At first, Chris reads the family's overly accommodating behavior as nervous attempts to deal with their daughter's interracial relationship, but as the weekend progresses, a series of increasingly disturbing discoveries lead him to a truth that he never could have imagined." This film destroyed my expectations. Jordan Peele did an excellent job writing and directing a truely terrifying horror film. This film had everything perfect. The acting was excellent, the soundtrack was so well composed, the directing was excellent. An all round excellent film. Daniel Kaluuya was excellent in this film. He played the character so well. I see a bright acting career. Jordan Peele also has a bright career in writing and directing, this film is an excellent example of how amazing horror films can be without being cliche. The soundtrack was so chilling and fit the film. The runtime was perfect and the pace of the film was excellent. Overall, an amazing example of horror at its finest. Definitely one of the best horror films in the last 17 years, possibly even more. The best film of 2017 this definitely is.

It's the new movie everyone is talking about and critics are raving about, as for me, I couldn't wait to get out...of the theater. Guess who's coming to dinner? It's a black man coming home to a rich suburban white families house for the weekend, and despite their black servants, they're extremely nice to their daughters new boyfriend, too nice, something weird is going on. Yes, something weird is going on, only Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya) is too stupid to realize it! He's so deeply in love with his girlfriend of all of four months, that not only can't he see what's going on right in front of his face, but he doesn't try to talk to her about it, he doesn't try to investigate any of it, he just sort of goes with the flow. People are raving about this noir thriller, when it is one of the most poorly written films I've seen in a while. Major plot holes aside for the moment, there is absolutely no character development, no chemistry between the actors, and worst of all they don't even reveal the main plot until twenty minutes before the thing is over! Yes, it's weird, yes, something is going on, but the writers don't even hint at what that is! They don't even give us a chance to figure out what it could possibly be. At first it was interesting and I was hoping there would be clues to help us figure out what might be going on, that maybe Chris would find evidence or over hear something, but no such luck. Maybe there could have been a scene without him, that gave us some insight, there was absolutely nothing until the very end, when it was all thrust into our faces and even then it really didn't make a whole lot of sense. Without giving anything away, they never answer the fundamental question, why black people? I never liked traditional noir, but at least most of the time the acting is good and you have some idea of what's going on. This film is just one big circle of confusion and to be honest with you, aside from some terrific comic relief, I hated every minute of it.
Awesooooooome! Enough said.

#GetOut is way boring, derivative, generic... but let's start from the top; most of the characters are caricatures. Except for the underdeveloped protagonist who we never get a chance to relate or empathize with, and his co-star whose character is too predictable by the direction of the film, even when Jordan Peele made a very poor set-up for her twist and had to do it in the middle of the third act.

The script is very lazy; 75% of this painfully slow movie is basically something that should just be set-up in the teaser alone. All the key factors for the resolution happen way too conveniently and are crammed in a pace-breaking, rapid Act III. 

The comedy relief moments--even though unfitting for the theme and tone of the film--are actually the most memorable scenes. This alone should tell you how much of a mess this is.

I loved the marketing for Get Out. It didn't quite give you the plot, whereas most trailers simply give out alot. It actually sort of leads you to believe the plot will be simple and predicable. Its got to be about white privilege or talking down to white audiences. You've probably read a few articles about how it flips the race thing on its head, not simply being about ignorant racist southerners, whose brand we've seen all too often. That it does do. Also, if you have been listening to comparisons, Guess Who's Coming To Dinner, Stepford Wive's and Rosemary's Baby are certainly influences on Jordan Peele. Like Quintin Tarantino he borrows, never bites, from those inspirations. Its from half of Key & Peele, so It's funny, witty and then surprisingly scary. Apparently JP has 9 more horror films like this in his bandolier

Childish Gambino's song Redbone plays over the introduction, perfectly fitting the tone of the movie as it demands people "Stay Woke!". Allison Williams is one of my favorite characters as Rose, but the two male leads also help make the film all that it is. Daniel Kaluuya is believable in an accent that's not even close to his and Lil Rel Howery plays the everyman perfectly. In this day and age it seems like an operation such as the one going on in this Connecticut town wouldn't get far, especially if you have constant connection to someone outside like Howery. The casting of the family is also brilliant, each filling their role well as supporting characters. The townsfolk are also creepy, especially Atlanta's Keith Stanfield. This is a movie that seems like it never would have got made (like Wonder Woman), but it did and the world is all the better for it. He does well balancing the tone of the film throughout. Peele crafts a horror movie that feels fresh and new; a feat most horror movies only dream of.


In the beginning the film is pace is slow, a perfect set up for whats to come. By the end though it is thrilling, as all that build up comes to a worthy pay off. It's uncomfortable to notice all attempts by the main character to bond over black culture with the other African Americans in the town are failing. The only one who seems to not be acting odd is Rose and maybe with her help, he can get out of this weirdo situation. Visually it is fine and nothing is queer to the eye, but the story and delivery of an on point 'social thriller' is the main accomplishment of the film. This being the directors first outing no one could have saw this coming, and it makes the score a few steps higher because of what he managed to pull off.

'Get Out' has been advertised as a (comedy) horror flick, likely because Jason Blum (the guy who produced Insidious, The Visit, Split, etc.), but it's actually more of a thriller in my opinion. Most of the scares/violence are in the third act, really. The film's about Chris Washington, a black man, who visits Rose Armitage's (his girlfriend)'s house to meet her parents. There, he learns the terrible truth behind what the Armitage family. (I won't reveal anything beyond that as it could be considered as spoilers) The script is pretty damn good. Not a single cheesy line. Most of the comic relief comes from Washington's friend, Rod Williams, a police officer who tries to help in his situation. This is a thriller worthy of the critical and commercial acclaim it received. Go see it if you liked movies like '10 Cloverfield Lane'!

Before I write anything on this movie. I'd like to point out that everybody talks about this movie and how well it deals with racism towards blacks, what about racism towards whites? Yes it is actually possible to be racist to a white person everyone, and this movie can be quite a lot. Anyway, moving on: Get Out is a film about a guy going to meet his girlfriends parents for the first time, which he is unsure about doing as they don't know he is black. He is hesitant at first but finally agrees to it and they head to her parents farm-house. At first everything seems fine, but then our main character Chris (Played by Daniel Kaluuya), starts to notice things. After an awkward dinner the night before with his girlfriend Rose's (Played by Allison Williams) brother talking about how black people are so much stronger and could take anyone on in a fight, they decide to leave the next day. This doesn't happen as it turns out they have a dinner party planned. Things start to get really weird, such as Rose's mom putting Chris in hypnosis, shady shit going on, and a weird encounter with another person, things start to go awry very fast. I will admit with what I said about the racism thing, their are probably people out there who are like this. Get Out can be a fairly freaky, jump-scare cliche at times, but at other times it fails to impress. While having great acting, this movies plot didn't rope me in like the trailer did, and slowly just went downhill in my opinion. Albeit an awesome and satisfying ending, the movies lackluster storytelling is what lost it for me. I will admit, this movie does have a very interesting and well-crafted plot twist, so I enjoyed that, and a lot of humor also made this movie much more tolerable for me personally. To me, a mediocre movie with talented actors but lackluster plot. Not bad just not great, and for me it doesn't have re-watch-ability.

All in all, Get Out is an entertaining, funny and scary, thought provoking thrill ride that excels at everything it wants to be.

While the film feels a bit slow to get going, Get Out is an awesome time once everything sets into place. Perhaps the only issue I have with the movie is a scene involving a box in a closet, in which the 'convenience' factor is overbearing, but that's just one hiccup in an otherwise incredible, well-told story.

Jordan Peele's screenwriting/directorial debut is quite the leap, exchanging the comedic chops one might expect for a potent blend of social commentary, suspense and horror. Peele shows us a creepy upper-class suburban atmosphere, host to a mixed-race couple's "meet the parents" moment, with a thick, permeating air of uncertainty and alarm. Everyone seems overly accepting of Chris, hometown girl Rose's new black boyfriend, but there's a look to their gaze that might imply something else. The town's dark-skinned residents, however, are less reserved. They behave like marionettes, Stepford Wives with an unnervingly wide smile: stiff, oddly-dressed and thoroughly disconcerting in posture and prose. At first glance, I worried that the metaphors Peele was searching for would be too on-the-nose and blunt, but his well paced, muti-layered story soon brushes those concerns away. The analogies remain, but they're nuanced and subtle, effective players in a larger tapestry. The greater story is twisting and unpredictable, a mystery that efficiently mixes legitimate worries with tension-breaking laughs and personal connections to throw us off the scent. We don't know who's in on the scheme (or what that scheme might be) until the very end, and for too long Chris is afraid to point fingers, lest he offend. Balancing social niceties with the increasing terror makes a great vehicle for this genre, and the prim-and-proper atmosphere only makes the occasional weird offhand remark or personal tick stick out that much more. An excellent small-scale nail-biter, it's richly crafted and sharp, with a sensitive finger right on the cultural pulse. Well worth the hype.

This movie has it all. It works well as a cleverly diabolical horror flick that kept me guessing while unravelling delicious reveals right up until the end. It adds a healthy dose of dreadful suspense as any good horror flick should. But that is not all, by any means. There is a deep and timely commentary about inter-race relations that is at times humorous and at other times puts the viewer ill at ease, which means its effective. Also as a delightful surprise the movie satirizes racist themes latent in liberalism. Thus the movie was deeply thought provoking. The only problems I had were minor, such as the race theme seemed overly superficial to me at times and some of the medical science elements of the plot were technically absurd, such that I had to suspend my beliefs to remain wrapped up in the plot. I should not fail to mention that the acting was superb, and Allison Williams was a standout. If you like a multi-dimensional film that excels in horror, mystery, suspense, while at the same time stimulating your mind with thoughts and perspective about race relations, then I highly recommend this film. I expect I will watch it a few more times for pure enjoyment and to explore further the race themes this movie puts forth.

This is a movie that I feel might take a couple more viewings for me to fully appreciate, and a healthy amount of conversations with people about it.  It's that sort of movie.  In a lot of ways, I think it's sort of the Stepford Wives of its time.  Without getting into spoilers, I will say it's not identical in terms of plot and twists, but there are some similarities.  But the biggest Stepford connection is the fact that it's social commentary on an issue of the time through a horror movie.  A daytime horror movie at that, at least for the most part.  There are nighttime scenes for sure, but a lot of the thrills take place in broad daylight in decidedly nonthreatening environments that are given a threatening edge.  This not only works as an intriguing approach to horror, it's also part of the movies themes and the conversation it's trying to create.  It's a very uneasy sort of movie, and hypnotic in it's thrills.  I watched it with a friend, and while at first we were sort of talking to each other while it was on, there reached a point when we literally stopped mid-sentence because the movie had grabbed us.
Objectively speaking, there's not much I can really find at fault with this movie.  From a technical and performance perspective, it's insanely well-made.  From a story perspective, it's good, though I do have a couple little nitpicks that seem like holes but work to get its point across.  My only real issue is that there's never really a point in the movie where you don't think somethings wrong, where you think maybe these people are okay.  From the get go, you know there's something up with this family, so despite their niceties you're just waiting for them to reveal the sinister side.  Once they do, you're waiting for the reveal of why their doing this.  When each of these turns happen, it just doesn't have quite the punch I would have liked.  I was drawn in to the films world, but it never really hit me, I was sort of just watching it happen.  Maybe that's just me, but I never felt the real impact of what was happening.  Having said that, the stuff that happens was still interesting to me, and I was curious where it was going to go.
This feels so close to being a modern horror/social commentary masterpiece, but it lacked a certain punch for me to really call it that.  As it stands though, it's still a damn good genre film with a lot of great performances from actors I really haven't seen in much and an astonishingly good directorial debut for Jordan Peele.  Maybe that opinion will change after a few more viewings.  Right now though, that's where I'm at.

Parliamo di questo film.
Un po' di numeri. Budget: $4,5m (un nonnulla). Incasso globale: $230m and counting (di cui 175m solo negli USA). Regia e sceneggiatura: il comico afroamericano Jordan Peele alla sua prima (!!) volta in cabina di regia. Ripeto: un comico al suo primo film da regista.

L'idea e il film arrivano nelle sale con un tempismo a dir poco perfetto. La satira (non forzata) riverbera con maggior forza nell'era Trumpiana e il film, in grado anche di far parecchio ridere, non colpisce tanto per i colpi di scena (dove si va a parare è facilmente intuibile) quanto per il controllo registico (a tratti sembra di vedere il miglior Shyamalan), la scrittura acuta, la recitazione fantastica (il protagonista sfrutta il volto magnificamente) e l'atmosfera semplicemente perfetta. Ci sono idee visive notevoli, inaspettati cambi di tono gestiti con maestria che rendono la parte centrale un rollercoaster isterico e inquietante, fino al più canonico ma non meno bello finale.

Original Review:
Waaaay over-rated.  Not scary enough to be called a horror.  And the laughs are underwhelming.  Baffled as to why people liked it so much.

WHAT I LIKED: On the one hand, 'Get Out' is undoubtedly a very gripping and engaging thriller indeed, but really it's more so a product of a whole host of different ingredients.
Yes Jordan Peele certainly isn't going for a straight genre piece here, as the story he writes is one of relative insanity that goes an awfully long way to literally explore its racial themes. Of course that approach to ideas could have easily come off as ridiculous and forced (as it has in many other movies such as 'The Age of Adeline') but it is surprisingly successful here because it doesn't take itself too seriously, and because it hooks you enough to stop you thinking about things too much.

Yes for one, Get Out is most definitely a film that invests and engages you extremely effectively as Peele not only builds a well-layered (and well-portrayed) lead character, but he also places him in plenty of genuinely tense and uncomfortable moments that are upped throughout and brought to life by the brilliant score and cinematography.

Secondly though, one can also say that none of that would have worked if it had dealt everything with a straight face and a steady hand, as the madness of the whole thing would have still felt unnatural. As such, Get Out delivers its crazy - if thematically grounded - story in a very humble and amusing manor that feels as though it doesn't take itself too seriously. In a way this is once again brought to life by the lead character, who travels through it all with a somewhat nervous brow and yet a calm and amused attitude that comes off exactly how one is supposed to perceive the whole experience as a viewer.

Match all that with some potentially eye-opening themes and what you get is a film that successfully challenges the expectations of the genre, its audience and its storytelling methods by using a pinch-of-salt approach with its underlying insanity to ensure it all feels organic and exciting. In the end it's a very enjoyable, engaging and amusing thriller, and whilst that may sound like an overly mixed bag, I can definitely say that none of those elements would have worked as well without each other.

WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: As it truly descends into madness in the final act, it does occasionally feel as though its forgotten how silly it has become.

VERDICT: A film that embraces its unique-ness in a way that engages and amuses; 'Get Out' is a surprising success from Jordan Peele that should hopefully get him more directorial work in the future.

Fairly entertaining black comedy masquerading as a horror film which, unfortunately, keeps itself back by engaging in a completely ridiculous story. But taken with an extremely large pinch of salt, it remains enjoyable if quite predictable. It's best watched not knowing anything other than the basic story - young inter-racial couple visit her well to do parents, but not is all quite as things seem. That's all you should be armed with before watching.

While a decent horror-comedy (and I use "horror" very loosely and "comedy" for that matter), it's still somewhat astonishing that it currently holds a 99% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes? It really isn't that good.

It probably makes for "better" viewing in a racially charged and hysterical country like the US. But, outside of that nation, it looks sort of twee. I say "hysterical", because there is a specific type of touchstone in the US regarding race and for obvious reasons. But that touchstone doesn't travel well and outside of that, 'Get Out' doesn't really have anything else to say. The story is utterly absurd and by itself in another film, would be rightly ripped apart. But, the film isn't really about its story. Getting into some mild spoilerific territory, 'Get Out' has some razor sharp satire regarding Liberal White America - which has strangely been misappropriated by outraged Conservatives in some quarters - and it contains some nice subtle comments (the black protagonist picks cotton at one point). But, while its wit is present, little else is to tell the truth. However, it's just enough to carry the film over the line, as it were.

Well done, but certainly not half as smart as some people think it is and it's scuppered with a couple of dodgy characters here and there. After the incredible reception it has received and abundant online hype, you may come away feeling a bit short changed.

You can feel 'what it's about' in terms of subtext but there's plenty of wriggle room and not every line or action is welded into the underlying idea; it leaves you some loose ends to think about after it's over. The general sense of unease and 'imposter syndrome' is masterfully built up. A smart, elegant horror to rate alongside 'The Babadook' and 'It Follows.'

Finally got to see this psychological horror comedy thriller about racial tension, and damn was it good. Jordan Peele is on fire here as writer and director, you'd never guess that it's his film debut. The pacing here is perfect as the tone cycles through the tension that builds throughout the film and the necessary moments of humor that momentarily break that tension. The script is also amazing tight with hints to what's really going on peppered throughout, I might have even guessed the truth if I had been prepared for the film to go as completely insane and dark as it does.

Daniel Kaluuya plays the lead and does a brilliant job playing this guy who thinks he's in your standard awkward and uncomfortable situation, only to discover that he's actually in a dangerous situation. The entire creepy white family is also brilliantly acted, Bradley Whitford and Allison Williams being the standouts. And there was one scene in which Betty Gabriel completely steals the movie for a few minutes, I hope she gets cast in more stuff.

Overall this is a must see, and hopefully an eye opener for people that don't realize how casually racist they are in their day to day lives. 9.5/10

Whenever a movie gets a perfect or near perfect Rotten Tomatoes score, I imagine people expect the film to be transcendent.  However, that's not what the score means.  It's basically the percent of critics that thought it was a good movie, not the average of how each critic rated the quality.  With that said, even though it's not one of my favorites this year, I thought this a really well done movie.  I appreciated the camera shots, score/soundtrack, acting, and script.  Peele does a really good job of balancing the horror/suspense and the comedy while avoiding the tropes of stupid characters and low-brow humor.  I think framing the film's commentaries on racial issues around the horror story made the metaphor for the life as an African American man more relatable without being overbearing.  Overall, it's not the funniest or scariest film out there, but it's sharp and entertaining enough to deserve it's 99% RT score.

Get out is a pretty interesting piece of cinema. Jordan Peele has a strong debut about an interracial couples weekend getaway to meet her parents.

The camera work is fantastic from the opening sequence and the film wastes no time and getting our attention. Part social satire, part horror film, get out makes you uncomfortable on both ends of the spectrum.  The family is strange from the beginning, and really you wonder what direction the movie is going to go in. You wonder what's up with these strange people. The
 performances from all actors involved is really what makes this film stand out. Every single actor and actress buy in with an intensity and realism that captivates the viewer.

The film does have comic relief which helped the film in certain areas.

I will say the first half of the film was great.  It kept you guessing, it had me intrigued, it made me wonder about this family and other things.  Was the girlfriend in on it? I had questions.
The last 20 minutes kept this film from being a complete 4 star film.
It fell into some of the cliches that plague other horror films.  Also the film revealed itself a little early into what was going on.  I will add that from the social satire aspect of the film, I felt it went a little too deep, even if some would say it was necessary.
All that being said the performances were so electric, and the twisted nature of the film really make this a unique must see flick.
Although the twist is guessable, this is oneof the best scripts n best screenplay.

S'il y a bien une oeuvre qui n'a pas volé sa belle réputation, c'est bien Get Out, premier film de Jordan Peele, une satire horrifique qui traite de la condition des Afro-Américains dans l'Amérique d'aujourd'hui à travers une sombre histoire de repas de famille qui tourne mal. Souvent drôle (Lil Rel Howery est excellent) mais assez peu effrayant, Get Out est rempli de petits éléments qu'on ne remarque qu'à la sortie de la salle et c'est la principale réussite de Peele, qui n'assomme jamais son spectateur sous cette symbolique pourtant omniprésente tout en faisant avancer son histoire à un rythme plaisant. Les acteurs sont parfaits, comme le sus-cité Lil Rel Howery, mais aussi Daniel Kaluuya, LaKeith Stanfield ou encore Allison Williams. Difficile de voir où cela va mener Jordan Peele, mais en l'état, c'est un quasi-coup de maître.

Desde sempre fui um fã do Jordan Peele graças ao trabalho dele no programa Key & Peele, um dos shows de comédia mais engraçados dos últimos anos. Sempre notei referências à clássicos do terror, mesmos nos sketches, dos dois e não foi tão surpreendente saber que ele iria dirigir um suspense psicológico. Mas além do clima, o que mais chama a atenção em "Get Out", trata-se de como o diretor aborda o racismo na sociedade em metáforas através do filme. É muito mais que um simples filme de susto, é uma grande obra que certamente será um divisor de águas no gênero. Parabéns, Peele!

Rose Armitage is taking her boyfriend, Chris Washington, to meet her parents for the first time.  He's a bit uneasy about how they'll treat him, as they're white and he's black.  However, her parents turn out to be unfazed and everything seems to be going fine.  Chris then starts to notice some weird behavioral traits with the black staff at the house.  The Armitages then throw a huge party and Chris ends up in some awkward conversations with the guests.  He initially just puts it down to the racial difference, but then the guests', and Armitages', motives start to appear more sinister. Chris decides it is time to get out...

Great directorial debut from Jordan Peele, who also wrote the script.  Peele was one half of the hilarious comedy duo Key and Peele, so you would be excused for thinking that his first movie would be a comedy.  Get Out is not a comedy.  It starts as a social commentary and ends as a horror-thriller.  

In both respects it is great, though I preferred the social drama aspect more.  Some very clever observations regarding race relations in the first half of the movie, and I imagine a fairly accurate depiction of the African-American experience.  As a horror-thriller the build up and plot development is very good but the ending felt a bit too easy and rushed.  The conclusion is also not very profound, which is a bit disappointing after all the social observations that came before. 

This said, the ending would be the only weak spot, and it only appears weak because the rest of the movie was so good.  

Peele does throw in some comedy moments, via the character of Rod Williams, and these are great.

Solid performances all round.  Daniel Kaluuya, as Chris, is probably the best of lot.  LilRel Howery, as Rod Williams, almost steals the show though.

When I went on Rotten Tomatoes, the rating on Get Out honestly shocked me: 99%? And 100% with top critics!!! I don't like to use rotten tomatoes to evaluate movies but damn! This is crazy. So I went to see it and... it is pretty good. Good for comedy, but horror?

Let me get it straight first: I think it is a very good movie! It is smart, well-shot and original. I think it tangled a very taboo subject and successfully. It asked the question: are really comfortable with racial differences. Unlike 90% of the movies today that treated way too seriously than it is, it poked fun of it by showing some of the social awkwardness. They would keep on saying things like "black is the new white" and "I would vote for Obama a third time" but on the other hand gave the main character with a strange eye. Admitted we all have it once in a while when we first meet diversity. It poked fun of people's political correctness yet ignorance on the inside. I find it funny and refreshing. However, the problem is this kept on repeating and feel very unrealistic. I felt like I was watching an M Night Shyamalan. Speaking of which, at times I even wondered if the film directed by him because there were so many similarities to his styles, such as the awkward dialogues, constant and random close ups and most importantly, very out of nowhere twist which I won't spoil.

I did like the cinematography. I liked the set. The house looked like familiar yet unique. It looks like somewhere your neighbor lives but to me it also felt like one of those southern cotton farm in the old times. It gave me a sense of uncomfartability but it doesn't creep me out, which I would expect from an horror film. I think the problem is that everything is way too well polished. By that I meant that every things looked way too clean and it felt the budget was way bigger than it was (5 mil). Split on the other hand, had a slightly bigger budget but it had a more indie look, which helped to raise the suspense and dread. One thing I did like is the sunken place. I won't spoil it, because it is hard to describe anyways, but just watch.....

The big problem is that the comedy went too far, especially from the actor Lil Rel Howery. He is very good and very likable, but his section is so over-the-top that it clashes with the tone of the movie. Long story short, I liked it as a social commentary rather than a thriller or horror film. I felt the advertising is very misleading. There were many plot holes, which again, I don't want to spoil. Good Movie, but great, not really!!

Get Out effectively turns Guess Who's Coming to Dinner into a high-concept thriller. The tension swells and the atmosphere soon grows unbearably creepy. But the film isn't half as intelligent nor as unpredictable as it thinks it is.
Writer-Director Jordan Peele's approach is fresh and ferocious, but it isn't forward-thinking. In short, the film falls apart long before the third act, due to predictable plot developments followed by Mr Peele's complete failure to realise that his high-concept premise has no need for sci-fi MacGuffins. 
The film is at its best during its early moments of Twilight Zone obscurity. The majority of which are skin-crawlingly creepy thanks to some fantastic secondary performances.
The film is at its worst, however, when it tries to paper its self-torn cracks with mad scientist mumbo jumbo. One development in particular is left not only hanging in thin air, but also distracting from the oblique aura of psycho-racial tension Mr Peele had previously worked so hard to build.

Get Out may not be a masterpiece, as some people claim it is, but you'd be hard pressed to find a movie that's so exciting and fun while simultaneously communicating a problem in modern society. In short, it is without a doubt one of the best films to come out so far this year, especially when compared to its terrible January/February competition, but it is far from a perfect film.  

The strongest element of the film is the creative and innovative script, by a relatively large margin. Peele demonstrates his trademark creativity with the extremely clever and somewhat subtle signs which are used to gradually build the tension, while simultaneously delivering useful exposition. In doing this, Peele ensures that the movie does not overstay its welcome, while still telling a complete, satisfying, and intriguing story. Two other major strengths that Get Out has are the masterful acting and extraordinary pacing. Lead actor Daniel Kaluuya delivers an incredibly authentic performance as the protagonist, Chris. Kaluuya manages to deliver a mind blowing performance filled with authenticity, from his convincing line delivery to his eerily realistic body languages. Rose (Allison Williams), Rod (LiRel Howlery), and the rest of the supporting cast all deliver extremely solid performances to complement Kaluuya, though none quite compare to his brilliant performance. Peele does a truly wonderful job of pacing the film, as he is able to keep the film suspenseful and interesting for the first act, increase the intensity in the second act, and finish strong with an impactful ending that audiences will not soon forget. At no point does the film feel rushed or does it drag on, it is as close to a perfect balance as one can get. 

This movie only had a couple of major shortcomings, though they ultimately did not do much to hinder my enjoyment of the film. A few times throughout the film, there are manufactured jump-scares, or jump-scares that would not occur in the movie's universe. For example, in one scene, a character is faintly seen lurking in the background, and when the character reveals herself, Peele inserts a slam, which is  cheap and lazy way to scare the audience. Also the plot is stretched a bit thin for this 1 hour and 44 minute film. At no point does it drag, but there is only so much you can do with a plot like this. 

Get Out is one of the most dynamic films of 2017 thus far, working very well on nearly every level, all the while seamlessly working in valuable social commentary without it seeming forced or ham-fisted. Jordan Peele certainly exceeds all expectations in his directorial debut, so if you want to see the best horror/comedy/thrillers in months, definitely check this one out.

Finally got round to seeing "Get Out" and I'm so glad that I did. It is without doubt one of the best horror thrillers films I've seen in years, a superbly crafted experience from start to finish. 
It's tense, atmospheric, and has a great old fashioned horror soundtrack complete with screeching violins. It's intricately paced and the last 20 is brutally intense. 
To go into the plot would give to much away but suffice to say a typical 'meet the parents' set up goes horribly horribly wrong. There are twists galore and it's all done with such finesse that I'm struggling to find something that I didn't like. The ending may be slightly too 'out there' for some but I liked it and it deserves all the success it is getting.

Get Out começa como um filme único. Discute o racismo de forma incrível, tocando no assunto seguidamente e explorando-o como uma bolha ameaçadora e criadora de tensão na história. A todo momento você sente certo desconforto (especialmente se for negro) trabalhado cuidadosamente pelo roteiro. Get Out é certamente o primeiro filme que vi relacionar de modo tão intenso a variável e agregá-la sem ser piegas ou cansativa.
Entretanto, a medida em que a história avança e as alternativas do roteiro se traçam e definem, há uma queda na força da história. Apesar de se tratar de um terror psicológico construído em torno de um ambiente estranho e incomum, a partir de certo ponto a história não é tão diferente assim de outras boas ideias que já vimos antes. 
Para não revelar muito do plot, de muito bom está a belíssima Allison Willians, a construção da ideia, bastante interessante, e como se revela no filme e a boa atuação de Daniel Kaluuya. 
Não é o meu preferido dos últimos anos mas é um ótimo filme.

Jordan Peele's directorial debut may not be what fans were expecting from the comedian, but it's a clever and confident genre mashup that expertly blends suspense and humor with biting social commentary on race relations. This scathing satire is the perfect horror film for the post-Obama era, taking a razor-sharp scalpel to white liberal attitudes on race. Peele succeeds where sometimes even more experienced filmmakers fail: He's made an agile entertainment whose social and cultural observations are woven so tightly into the fabric that you're laughing even as you're thinking, and vice-versa. What makes Get Out more than just a slam-bang scarefest is that, in its own darkly satiric way, it is also a movie about racial paranoia that captures the zeitgeist in ways that many more "prestigious" movies don't. I think studios need to take more chances on films like this. Films that try to be different and push boundaries. Get Out is bold and daring and most importantly, unique. A marvel of tightly controlled pacing, off-kilter visuals, and rich atmosphere, Peele's film owes a good deal of its exquisite shocks to the claustrophobic terrors of Rosemary's Baby and the manicured dread of Bryan Forbes's The Stepford Wives. Funny, scary, and thought-provoking, Get Out seamlessly weaves its trenchant social critiques into a brilliantly effective and entertaining horror/comedy thrill ride.

Expertly crafted, but suffers from an inability to maintain its initial momentum.  The set-up, a middle class black man entering an upper class home where the only other black faces are the servants, is the perfect fodder for a paranoid horror mystery and its handled expertly for a first time helmer.  But it ends up somewhere far more generic than youd expect, and it never quite decides if the allegories you think its setting up are a double bluff.  The politics of the first half are intriguing for such a mainstream film, minutely dissecting the way casual racism can come from the most unexpected sources, but this does mean that some of the characterisation doesnt stand up to scrutiny when the film starts dropping surprised later on.  Its good, perhaps even very good, but its a step behind where its reputation suggest.

I haven't seen a horror movie this good since the original 1970s Wicker Man. Every aspect of this movie was perfect. It was scary, funny, extremely thought-provoking, and has plenty of those great "epiphany" moments when you realize something new about what's going on. All of the actors played their parts extremely well, although it was not as apparent the first time around as it was the second time watching it, which I HIGHLY recommend everyone do. You will understand so much more the second time and see so many small things you didn't catch the first time. I won't give any spoilers, I believe I have said enough. And for someone who has never written a film review, because I am highly critical of most films to the point that I don't care to leave reviews, I can't recommend this one enough!

Now here is a great horror film. Probably surprising, considering it's from the mind of Jordan Peele, a comedian best known for Key & Peele on Comedy Central. Apparently he has a knack for horror, as well. It throws away all of the disgusting, demeaning horror flicks that have defined the genre for the last decade; all of the movies that must strip away their own dignity and bring themselves to such grisly, low levels in a cheap attempt to get a scare. This movie is scarier than all of them, and earns its scares. 
	 It stars Daniel Kaluuya as Chris, a young black man who is going up to visit his white girlfriend's family. His girlfriend, Rose (Allison Williams), and her parents are white, middle-class, liberals, who "would have voted for Obama a third time" if they could. Even so, Chris picks up what he perceives to be the subtle racism present in even these families. Of course, this being a horror film, it turns out to be something much more sinister. 
	This movie is branded as a "horror-comedy," which I would disagree with. Sure, there's some comic relief, mostly thanks to one character, but this is a horror film, and even more so a mystery. And when the mystery is finally revealed towards the end, it makes everything that happened before it all the more creepy. After this revelation occurs is when the movie becomes a classical horror film, and the final act is done smartly and very entertainingly. 
	The way this movie tackles racism is also very smart. Unlike last year's overblown Zootopia, this film deals with serious political issues without forgetting to make a movie. Subtle racism is the theme here; not the blatant racism found in the KKK or the alt-right, but in everyday, middle-class, even liberal folks who try so hard to accept African-Americans that they end up simply making them more uncomfortable. It takes the concept of subtle racism and builds a fantasy out of it; a sort of "what if" question kind of film that takes a real element in our society and imagines a creative backstory behind it. This film isn't as politically charged as you might think, though; there is smart social commentary, but not so much that it becomes an ideological preach. There's a really good, scary story here that compliments its message rather than exclusively becoming it. 
	The end of the film is fun, entertaining, and thrilling, like any good horror movie ending should be - think Halloween and The Shining. It's not, as the trailers seem to be trying to make us think, a weird, random, nonsensical ghost story. It's neither supernatural nor a slasher; Peele comes up with a unique horror concept that lends itself to one of the best horror movies in recent years. It's not gloomy, depressing, or demeaning; even in its darkest moments, there's fun, excitement, thrills, and, in the most classical sense of the word, horror.

I usually watch horror films in the privacy of my home. Why? So I can hit the fast-forward, mute or pause buttons whenever I feel the need! It's my emotional safety key.

The efforts of Key and Peele on Comedy Central are what I consider to be the edgiest, most important comedy work dealing with social issues that I have seen right alongside with Amy Schumer's fearless feminist takes on her own series at that network.
So, I got brave and took a friend to see it with me during the daylight! A matinee! "Yes! We can watch it safely" I thought.
It was fabulous! We were screaming at the screen, "Get! Out! Now!"
The lead actor, Daniel Kaluuya, was in another scary piece I'd seen in a British Sci Fi series called, Black Mirror - a segment titled 'Fifteen Million Merits'. He's great to watch and his arc in Get Out is wonderful.
I don't want to spoil a thing and recommend seeing it without watching or listening or reading ANYTHING beforehand.

WOW, i mean, i don't even know where to start...... This movie came completely out of nowhere, who knew that Jordan Peele's directorial debut would be this fucking good. 'Get Out' is a Horror/Comedy about Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) who goes on a trip to visit his girlfriend Rose's (Allison Williams) parents whose odd behaviour towards this interracial couple gets increasingly more concerning for Chris during their stay. Ever since reading the initial synopsis for this film i was completely IN just based on that alone, it sounded very intriguing and more importantly it was inherently original, the type of film more people need to go and see. And this movie completely delivered and surpassed my expectations on almost all fronts. This movie highlights a perfect application of Horror, with plenty of unsettling imagery, and Peele blends it perfectly with hints of comedy that hit EVERY time and did not feel out of place at all. The performances here are also so riveting and only enhance the very unsettling nature of this film. 

I will start with commending Jordan Peele on his success with this film, not only was this a venture away from the comedic material he is known for as one half of 'Key and Peele' but this was also his directorial debut which is insane. Isn't it funny how this comedic actor can take a leap of faith into Horror for his directorial debut and accomplish something greater than most modern horror directors. What makes this film so well crafted is the way he expertly blends themes of horror with comedy and also incorporates subtle social commentary here and there that you can notice yet doesn't take you out of the film. I mean there are scenes in this film that are terrifying and unsettling but are also really fucking funny. He manages to terrify you right in the middle of some quite humorous scenes and it blends perfectly in ways i can't possible explain to you through words. And forget creepy imagery, there are some scenes where there is nothing even slightly scary on the screen and just through the use of very confronting camera placement you feel so uneasy you just want to squirm in your seat. 

One incredible thing to note with this film is that typically you see in horror films sequences of building suspense towards multiple big terrifying scary moments scattered throughout. But what is really cool here is that the suspense is being built up constantly throughout the entire film towards a final 20 minutes or so that is so balls to the fucking wall crazy that your mind will be blown. The film grabs you early on and for an hour and 40 minutes it is slowly tightening its grip keeping you locked in your seat and delivering with one of the best climaxes in a horror film that i've ever seen. It goes to places you never even imagined it would go and it turns what is a fantastic premise into an incredible story. The pacing is crucial to the suspense factor and the way it gets progressively faster as the film goes on works so damn well. It gives the film plenty of time early on to introduce characters, get you to care about them, and implement little hints here and there of things to come. And it also allows the film to close out on a high note where it does not mess around.

And i mentioned the performances briefly but you cannot look past them when thinking about this movie. Daniel Kaluuya and Allison Williams were phenomenal as this couple and i was completely sucked into every one of their scenes and believed all of their exchanges because they were all so goddamn natural. The film focuses on Daniel's character predominantly so that is the character we are experiencing the film through and he does a great job at really letting you connect and relate with him. The parents though, OMG they were fucking great. Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener were intriguing, unsettling, and haunting, a lot of the time without even saying a word. And also this guy deserves a mention also; LilRel Howery plays Chris' friend Rod Williams in the film and he is fucking hilarious. He provides the majority of the larger comedic moments and his timing was on point 100% of the time. Having a straight up purely comedic character in this film that offers a perfect blend of Horror and Comedy could have been very out of place but it worked so damn well. 

So in the end, yeh, there really wasn't anything i did not like about this movie, the story was great and hooked me in right from the get-go, the characters and performances were all so well introduced and developed. The way Jordan Peele blended Horror and Comedy so seamlessly was incredible especially for his directorial debut. Now the only question looming is was it a fluke or can he deliver this sort of quality again and again and transition into a continuously successful director? Only time can tell. If you haven't gathered this already then YES you should most definitely see this movie, it doesn't release in Australia until May the 4th (Be With You) so until then just wait in anticipation.

Like many other such movies, and the 2015 movie The Invitation comes to mind, something about what's going on simply didn't feel plausible or believable enough. Honestly, the biggest steaming pile of equinine fecal matter I've watched in over a decade. Spring Breakers was more entertaining than this convoluted mess of plot holes. Tries hard but it ultimately failed terribly. The resolution at the climax attempted to emulate the revenge of the black man over centuries of white suppression but succeeded only in obnoxiously extolling the virtues of the African race, ironically, perpetuating a whole bunch of racial stereotypes about the black community.

I'm pretty sure I'm not the first person to say I was completely taken by surprise when it turned out that not only did Get Out receive near-perfect reviews, but it was actually directed by Jordan Peele. I repeat, JORDAN PEELE, a guy who's done almost nothing but comedic work. Granted, he's a great comedic talent, but this movie shows that he might actually be a force to recon with!

The film itself worked really well in terms of structure, cinematography and acting. It follows some horror tropes from the past, but it utilizes a more unique premise and a gradual reveal of its twists and beautiful shots to keep things engaging. In all honesty though, I found the film to be more unsettling than scary. It is definitely the good kind of unsettling however. On top of that, it provokes some interesting thoughts about racism which I won't spoil for you here. I probably wouldn't say it's a game changer in the horror genre, especially since there are a few moments that end up leaving me questioning things rather than trying to put the pieces together, but in just the way it's executed, it certainly is well-made.

It's definitely worth checking out if you're looking for a worthwhile recent Hollywood film, as it has a very good chance of being one of the best films of this year!

Catching up on Get Out a little later than most, I knew to have my expectations high, but I didn't know precisely how high. Based on the trailers and director Jordan Peele's sketch comedy pedigree, I expected a subversive and satirical take on suburban racism, kind of like if Cabin in the Woods was more interested in the world around it than horror tropes (the presence of Bradley Whitford certainly didn't hurt that expectation). Suffice to say, Get Out is not the film I prejudged it to be. It's insights into white-collar racism are sharp, but I expected that. It has its moments of deadpan hilarity, but I expected that. What I didn't expect is how terrifying and tense the film is, and how visually distinctive and original Peele's production is. This is not only a movie that deftly highlights a rift in the modern discussion about race, but it is also 2017's answer to It Follows and The Witch as an original vision in horror, and an announcement of Jordan Peele as a filmmaker well worth following.

From the mind of Jordan Peele comes one of the more surprising thrillers in recent memory: Get Out. There is a crazy amount of hype around this film and normally that can kill everything, but this is actually a film that earns every bit of it. While there is one slight issue here, Get Out is a rare film that walks the line between satire and social awareness and delivers a great time at the movies.

There is a lot in this film that works but what is definitely the most prominent feature of this film is Jordan Peele's eye in the director's chair. This is such an ornate film that it almost seems like an independent arthouse project. More importantly, Peele even throws in minuscule details that hint towards the future twists in the plot. The color pallet, the use of certain camera shots, all the way down to small visual details, Peele has crafted a film in the way that Stanley Kubrick himself would have been pleased to see. 

The script by Jordan Peele is no slouch and does arguably more work here than the rest of the crew involved. The story is simple with a interracial couple taking a weekend for a white girl to introduce her black boyfriend to her family. However things get awkward and from there we are thrust into a thriller with twists and turns that will do more than keep you engaged. The beauty of the script is that there is comedy in parts as well as heavy drama with horror like elements, but yet it does address these social issues that don't often get brought up. Not once did I feel like the issues took precedent over the story but rather uses them to back up the thriller aspect of the film. Anytime a film can accomplish that in a way that you might not even notice it, there is something special about it.

There is one major issue with the script though and that is that there is a bit of predictability about it. You can definitely see where the script is going in parts and this does get kind of obvious. While the events of the film are orchestrated in a great way and the overall end product does make this a small problem, you may sit there and think that you have seen this before.

The cast is fantastic and really do sell this film where it counts. A newer face in Hollywood named Daniel Kaluuya stars as Chris, the boyfriend, and he is hands down the best part of this film. Empathetic, funny, and more importantly shows astounding range; Kaluuya is definitely has a future thanks to this film. Allison Williams stars as the girlfriend, Rose, and does a great job. She is super effective in the role and plays her part like a champ. We also get some great roles from more familiar actors like Stephen Root, Catherine Keener, and Bradley Whitford. They all are great and are huge parts in really filling out the world of this film. However someone who actually almost steals the film is  Lil Rel Howery as Chris's best friend. He adds comedic relief in the best places and definitely makes this film feel like a complete experience.

Overall Get Out is nothing short of a fantastic horror/thriller. The story is relevant, the finished product is absolutely beautiful, and the cast sells this film incredibly well. While it is a bit predictable at times, Jordan Peele's directorial debut is a triumph and gives us as the audience something to enjoy as well as think about.

'Get Out' is billed as a horror film, but - no spoilers in this review! - it's really more of a mystery/tense thriller. It's shot really well and looks great (nice effort from first-time director Peele), with some smart use of the Alabama location and a good score. The premise is purposefully cryptic: "African-American man visits his Caucasian girlfriend's mysterious family estate". Chris (Kaluuya) is meeting Rose (Williams) parents - Missy (Keener) & Dean (Whitford) - for the first time, and they welcome him with open arms, even if the servants seem off.

It's not all about race, but it is a key aspect of the film and handled quite well. The two leads easily carry the film, both having some great scenes. However, the best bits are probably whenever Chris' friend Rod (Howery) is on screen, being hilarious and boisterous, even though often by phone. The humour and some slow bits do well to make the surprises seem even more shocking. 

The twist isn't as big as 'Cabin in the Woods' or 'The Sixth Sense', but the final 20min is certainly one of the better endings to a thriller/horror film you'll see for a while! Bit of a slow build up in parts, but a very exciting finish and it's all over in 100min.

The two biggest complaints I've seen on here are:

1.) Bad/"Wooden" acting -- do I have to explain why the acting would see that way? Everybody in the film was pretty great; let's not forget that it's technically a horror movie, a genre known for bad acting, and what we get here was amazing by comparison.

2.) Predictable -- Okay, if you're calling it "predictable" then I'm pretty sure you didn't actually watch (or finish) the movie. Of course we knew the basic premise from the trailer, but nobody could have predicted the reveal in Act 3.

This movie has a 99% rating for a reason and calling it the "worst movie I've ever seen" is just silly. It's also not really "racist" and even if it was, get over it -- white people can deal with a little racism after decades of films, tv shows, cartoons, etc that are racist as hell. Just look at pre-1950's cartoon.

The one critique I can kind of understand is that it's not particularly "scary," but what exactly were you expecting? It's more of a creepy psychological thriller with a slow burn. Also, I'd say this wouldn't be as scary to white people for obvious reasons, so there's that.

In Jordan Peeles debut, he officially declares his independence, not only from the comedic partnership of Key & Peele but also from their sketch comedy roots; nevertheless, it still lurks in the background in a film that comes across as a sketch idea that ends up translating better than expected in feature length form. There is more creepiness and dark humour than proper horror here, even though the last 15 minutes is pure blood and gore and all the more satisfying for it. Peeles directing is assured and his own script delivers an unsettling somethings not quite right feeling against the idyllic and very white suburbia setting, while Bradley Whitford, Allison Williams and Catherine Keener bring The Stepford Wives/Rosemarys Baby vibe on. Perhaps it is done so well, there seems to be little room left for any doubts or surprises on the fate of the unsuspecting black boyfriend, played with wide-eyed innocence by newcomer Daniel Kaluuya. As with most films of this genre, the final act has convenient plot contrivances that are papered over by one-liners but it is to the films credit that it still never loses its charm or its hold over its audience. While the film touches on issues such as race and race relations, this Twilight Zone take on Guess Whos Coming to Dinner is clever and thoughtful, timely even, but hardly groundbreaking and its satirical value is limited. In other words, one shouldnt read too much into what is essentially a fun piece of escapist entertainment.

Get Out features a surprisingly fantastic, stirring performance from Daniel Kaluuya, who's career I'd followed mostly through British television (Skins, Black Mirror, Psychoville...etc) and always enjoyed his performances however was so surprised with his film capabilities. The entire cast is brilliant, particularly Kaluuya and Catherine Keener who plays hypnotic matriarch Missy. The plot is much more serious and emotional than I had anticipated and the actual plot was a huge surprise, as I thought I was in store for another by the numbers slasher film, however the actual themes at hand and underlining racial satire of the film are so intelligent. Frightening, fascinating and even often funny, Get Out is set to be one of the strongest horror films of the year for sure.

Rose is the young, attractive, white college coed acts as the seducer of black folks into a sordid scheme of kidnaping, hypnosis and brain transplantation organ-ized and operated by her hypnotist mom, Missy, and surgeon dad, Dean. A surprisingly good film!
The first act of the film follows a young white lady Rose taking her black partner Chris being introduced to the parents.
Rich, Democrat parents. They rejoice in telling everyone how they would have voted for the previous US President Obama for a third term if possible.
However they do show undertones of racism. Not least in having black 'servants' that reminded me of Gone With The Wind and 12 Years A Slave.
The parents proceed to host a big house party that introduces the audience to more oddball characters that more enhance the racist feeling of the film.
The final act of the film turns into a typical horror bloodfest in the vein of films such as The Saw franchise.
The film benefits from not having a 'known' cast. The performances from all the cast are excellent.
Parts of the film are comedic in their script raising a few chuckles amongst the audience.
The movie has a B movie feel in that respect. Indeed it was shot in only 28 days.
However make no mistake this is far better than the B movie horrors I watch.

Comedian Jordan Peele's directorial debut is a fantastic horror film about a black guy visiting his white girlfriend's family for the weekend...but things go from being just a little bit weird to downright frightening.  It had this sense of Lovecraft that I am always into....and the message and themes are just relevant and on point.  The fact that this is a comedian's directorial debut is crazy, it is so wonderfully shot and put together...usually a comedian trying to break into the movies or directing start with, well, comedies!  The fact that Peel had such a strong story and then came in first time directing with such a sure hand makes him a filmmaker I want to watch out for.  A fantastic debut.

Alright, let's talk about Get Out, a directorial debut by Jordan Peele (of Comedy Central's Key & Peele) who also wrote and produced the film. Movies in the horror genre are not extremely difficult to make and are often the most criticized due to the repetitiveness of their plot lines (someone/something is haunted, unstoppable killer is on the loose, bodily fluids aplenty, you get the idea). However, Get Out succeeds in this category by targeting racism head on in an unexpected way and injecting an even amount of comedy in the film to keep audiences both enthralled in laughter and frightened at the reality of its premise.

After opening with a scene of a black man getting kidnapped in the dead of night, Get Out begins with biracial couple Chris Washington and Rose Armitage who are packing for a trip to meet and spend the weekend with Rose's parents. Rose sees this as the perfect opportunity for her family to meet Chris, yet Chris is slightly nervous to meet them because he is black and Rose (and her liberal family) are white. Rose assures him that her parents are quite liberal and excepting, making his tension simmer but not dilute itself completely by this reassurance. As Rose and Chris arrive to her parents home, they meet Rose's father Dean (a successful surgeon), her mother Missy (a hypnotherapist), and her off-kilter brother Jeremy. Chris also meets the house gardener and the maid, who are black and seem harmless enough but slightly off. Things start to take an immediate turn into twilight zone as Chris is hypnotized by Missy on the first evening of his stay, after sneaking to smoke a cigarette, and begins to notice strange patterns within the few black people he meets; especially during a "planned" Armitage family get-together throughout the weekend that Rose conveniently forgot to mention to Chris. His paranoia leads him to conclude that something is definitely wrong and as he tries to escape, (aided via phone by his best friend Rod, played by a hysterically terrific LilRey Howery) he uncovers a horrific truth about the inner workings of the Armitage family.

The uneasiness of this premise alone echoes memories of the Sidney Poitier classic "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner?" in which a "free-thinking" white woman introduces her black doctor fiance to her parents; a break-out progressive film of it's time back in 1967. The comedy and progressive ideology of that film blends with the racial and social tensions of Get Out which lead to an intelligent horror film. Daniel Kaluuya grounds the audience with a realistic portrayal (finally) of what a person in a horrifically charged situation like this would do and brings gravity to his character's narrative and backstory. What Daniel's character, Chris, uncovers of what exactly happens to the black community here may come as an unexpected twist but one that is expertly thought out and executed, leaving audiences talking and pondering about the nature of these ideas for sometime to come. Jordan Peele masterfully interjects these radical notions with precision and excellent timing, striking a balance between horror, comedy, and critical thinking; Get Out is laced with social commentary on the state of what it is to be a black male in today's society but also turns that idea on its head in this racially divided world. In many ways, Get Out manages to break these barriers and delivers an impressive commentary on the way the world views race relations today while entertaining and scaring the hell out of everyone. Get Out stands as one of this best films of the year so far, one everyone should make an effort to see.

Jordan Peele's directorial debut, Get Out, is a must see thriller.  In a film that finally shows a Black-American being attacked and targeted by a white majority, Peele was able to pull off suspense and intrigue.  We're so used to seeing the black person in the movie as a villain, a savage, and a drug-using/dealing criminal.   In this film, we see it being the exact opposite.  The Black-Americans in this film are honest, law abiding citizens who are respectable, just like they're-shockingly enough in Hollywood- normal people living normal lives.  This film paints a different picture than the ones we are used to seeing in a Hollywood film.


"Do they know I'm Black?"         My dad would vote for Obama a third time if he could, she says, as if to comfort his unease about meeting her white parents.  That about sums up the other characters interactions with him as well.

Imagine going to go meet the parents and being caught up in a culture that seemingly is overly "I'm not racist."- That is to say, the people who mean well, but still say and do racist things.

However, moving past that, this film manages to do something that many films before it have failed to do.  It manages to actually psych out the audience.  This movie left audiences on the edge of their seats.  The use of camera movements to portray a deeper story and to add to the raw emotions is outstanding.  The use of silence to fill a gap and leave the audience in suspense works perfectly.  The score added into the silent acting and use of camera

Allison Williams is cast perfectly as the loving, adoring girlfriend, Rose, who doesn't care that her boyfriend is black and who gets along exquisitely with Chris's (Daniel Kaluuya) best friend, Rod.

From the time we meet Rose's family, Chris feels uncomfortable, we can see and feel that.  Perhaps that it is the off-handed racism, perhaps it's a gut feeling.  Every time we see another black character, we see Chris getting more and more uncomfortable everything.  This comes to a tipping point when we see Lakeith Stanford's character, Andrew, lunge at our protagonist just for taking a picture of him after hearing and seeing the way he was speaking as if he were a cultured person living in a bygone era.

After this, things escalate from thriller to full-blown horror film that can leave audience members shocked if they aren't ready for it.

Peele manages to pull together so many underlying tones and bring them into the spotlight without the audience even knowing.  Audiences of all racial backgrounds have something to make them shift uncomfortably during this film because of it.  One such tone is the ode to slave auctions.  You'll have to watch the film to know where this comes from.  The feeling Chris has when he "sink[s] into the floor" is another one.

Overall, this film masterfully addresses the issues of anti-black rhetoric in America and can leave some white audience members uncomfortable and hateful of the film, but other folks deeply in love with the film and its relevance to today's world.

There is very little wrong with Jordan Peele's directorial debut film Get Out. The story takes off with Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya) and his girlfriend Rose Armitage (Allison Williams), packing to visit Rose's parents. When they arrive, they are welcoming enough, but Chris quickly realizes that something is strange about Rose's family and begins to see that any black people that are around the Armitage's world seem troubled and different. As Chris digs to unearth the truth, he is faced with something much more horrifying than he ever imagined. Jordan Peele proves he not only has an aptitude for direction but an imaginative story teller as well. 
The cast of the film was made up of talented individuals who augmented the quality of the movie. Daniel Kaluuya and Allison Williams play off each other very well as a convincing modern interracial couple. Williams even keeps the audience guessing as to whether her aligence lies with Chris or with her family. The actors playing Rose's family and the help that they keep around the house also do a terrific job of creating a peculiar atmosphere when they interact with each other. 
The aspect of the film that really drives it into something great is the intelligent way that it explores racism. Get out has subliminal messages dealing with race such as "the sunken place", the bingo game, and the Armitage's preference of using black people for their own personal gain. Peele wonderfully employs the topic of racism into the film while simultaneously not making the audience feel like its been forced in their faces. Packaged together, Get out is a must see thriller that you don't want to miss.

I hate to use the term "overrated" when describing a critically acclaimed, wildly hyped movie. Because I truly believe that if everyone loves a movie, it's because they had an enjoyable experience seeing it and think everyone else will as well.

However, in this particular situation, I'm making an exception. I found "Get Out" to be quite overrated, in an almost symbolic way. 

It's like white people are afraid to criticize this movie because they don't want to resemble the white characters in the movie. C'mon guys, stop being afraid of having an honest discourse with black people about race. You don't have to go out of your way to prove you're not racist.

Every single white character in this film, without exception, outwardly worships black people (they're stronger, better at taking photographs, smarter, have bigger penises, are faster etc.) but they're internally, quietly racist against them. This is a silly, shallow concept.

The black characters in the movie are strong, smart, superior. The white characters are hollow, shallow, and inferior. A far from nuanced approach to racial relations in America.

The movie is funny, it's got a few good scares. The TSA agent (his name escapes me) is a great comic relief, and has the most sense of any character in the picture.

But, the film is somewhat hollow. It's being heralded as some subversive peek behind the scenes of America's racial tensions, but... t's simply not.

When the Doctor is asked, "Why us? Why do you kidnap black people?"
His literal answer is, "I don't know."

Even the writers of the film weren't exactly sure of the purpose here. 

This is such a silly, shallow understanding of how white people view black people.

Really don't get what all the fuss is about. Really a silly idea. Allison Williams, looking unhealthy-skinny, is much too young for all the boyfriends she's supposedly had. And the idea of parents pimping their daughter out is something none of the reviewers have commented on and is hugely distasteful.

GET OUT-2017(R)-Mar. 25.
By:Clem The Movie Guy.

Get Out is the spine-chilling debut film of Jordan Peele, the one-half of the sketch comedy show duet "Key & Peele" with Keegan-Michael Key. Get Out follows Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya), a young black man who's been in a five-month relationship with his Caucasian girlfriend, Rose Armitage (Allison Williams.) Rose hasn't told her family that she is dating a black man & Chris is a little worried about how they are going to react when Rose takes him to meet the family for the weekend. Upon arriving at the private estate, Chris meets Rose's parents Dr. Dean Armitage (Bradley Whitford), a neurosurgeon & Dr. Missy Armitage (Catherine Keener), a creepy hypnotherapist as well as Rose's brother Jeremy (Caleb Landry Jones). While being given a tour of the house by Dean, Chris is curious to note that the family have two black servants working for them; Walter the groundskeeper (Marcus Henderson) & Georgina the maid/housekeeper (Betty Gabriel.) Dean tells Chris that the the two used to work for Dean's parents & he didn't feel comfortable letting them go after his parents' deaths. After a night of witnessing strange behavior by Walter & Georgina, Chris becomes uneasy, especially during the family's spring party featuring only older white people whose demeanor with Chris makes him distinctly uncomfortable. Realizing that he needs to "Get Out" of there, Chris soon discovers the horrifying truth of what can happen to black people when they ended up in an unfamiliar place. As a first time writer & director, Jorden Peele has made a smartly intense horror film with some very dark humor & chilling twists. The performances from the cast were phenomenal. Catherine Keener was scarier than hell. Get Out is s MUST-SEE FILM.

There's quite a lot to enjoy in this horror/thriller but I have to say I did feel deeply uncomfortable about aspects of the plot in which a white girl takes her black boyfriend for weekend with her parents. Always a tricky situation, filled with potential embarrassments and moments of social awkwardness, this rite of passage is nothing compared to what poor Daniel Kaluuya's character, Chris, has to put up with. The family and their friends are obsessed with the physical prowess and attributes of African-Americans and their interest has a dark motive. Owing  a great deal to movies like the Stepford Wives, Get Out has some interesting things to say about middle-class, white American society and attitudes but it felt rather laboured for my tastes and was ruined by some horrifically violent scenes which were unnecessarily graphic and gory. Not as spine-tingling, chilling or indeed funny as it could have been, this felt like a bit of a wasted opportunity.
