4.5/5: For a long time, Jordan Peele - of the comedy duo Key and Peele - has always discussed his dream of making a horror film that stood out from the rest. Get Out is that dream realized. Peele's debut is a clever dark satire and provocative horror film that is sure to be a modern classic, mostly because of its racial themes in this age. 

The cast is excellent, from Daniel Kaluuya as the lead, to Bradley Whitford, an outstanding Allison Williams, and the hilarious Lil Rey Howery. The scares are well done (though, a few don't make sense once the reveal is made), the tension is felt throughout, the world is very realized, and the twists and turns kept me on the edge of my seat. There are also some really darkly humorous and intentionally awkward moments that were perfect in adding the element of discomfort. This is a movie that is meant to make the audience realize that - despite the over-the-top plot at play, there is a lot of real-world racial tension that needs to be expressed.

My only fear is that, because Get Out is currently at 100% on Rotten Tomatoes, that people are expecting this to be the greatest film ever made, and may leave overhyped and underwhelmed. It's not The Shining in terms of horror movies, but it is certainly a memorable, fun, and creepy film experience people will be talking about for years to come.

Out of all the possible genre combinations, horror and comedy are probably the most difficult to combine.  I'm not sure if first time director Jordan Peele impresses more with that particular balance, or with his ability to effectively display social commentary.

Blumhouse Productions is putting together quite the resume. Their films continue to make bank at the box office, but the diversity of their horror features are nothing to scoff at either.  Just in the last few years alone they've made films like The Gift, The Visit, Split, and now Get Out.  All original twists on the horror/thriller genre.  Get Out may be the most impressive yet.

I always talk about my disconnect with the horror genre and how I don't find much substance with 75% of the films.  Get Out turns the genre on its head, doesn't rely on jump scares, is surrounded by tremendous performances, and has a socially relevant script.  It is so rare for a film to have a socially relevant message without feeling too political or one sided.  I can't tell you how many times I've appreciated what a film or a TV show is saying, but I get turned off by the way it's portrayed.  Get Out manages to make an entertaining horror/thriller, while also commenting on unintentional and benevolent racism coming from a white family towards their daughter's new boyfriend, an African American.

It's the racism most people don't normally think about.  The people who say they aren't racist because they "voted for Barack Obama" or maybe because "Tiger Woods is their favorite athlete".  Films like 12 Years of Slave and the recent documentary, 13th, are important.  But it's films like Get Out that are more effective because they are giving the same message in a different way.  Brilliantly written and structured, Peele gets the most out of his actors and times the laughs and scares in an effective manner.  Please go out and support an original film like Get Out.  You won't be disappointed.

GUESS WHO'S NOT COMING HOME FROM DINNER? - My Review of GET OUT (3 1/2 Stars)

For me, the best horror films serve as analogies for some of our most deeply rooted fears, whether it be disease, death, powerlessness, loneliness or even discomfort.  Leave it to writer/director Jordan Peele to come up with a wholly original scare concept.  With GET OUT, he takes white society's co-opting of black culture and turns it into something insidious. Be afraid. Be very afraid!  

After a highly effective, SCREAM-esque opening sequence, GET OUT follows Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya, so good in BLACK MIRROR's "Fifteen Million Merits" episode) who sets off to the country with his new girlfriend Rose Armitage (GIRLS' Allison Williams) to meet her family.  Despite the fact that she tells him he's her first black boyfriend, Rose insists her parents, while uncool, have completely liberal leanings.  This opening sections does a great job at establishing Chris and Rose's lovely chemistry, but the pacing felt off.  I wished editor Gregory Plotkin, who knows a thing or two about brisk horror films, having cut 4 of the PARANORMAL ACTIVITY movies, had convinced Peele to tighten things up.  It really would have benefitted from losing a good 10 minutes, as many of the scenes suffer from a bit of slackness.  It's not so much about losing scenes as it is about pacing the whole thing up during the first half.  

Regardless, GET OUT truly knows how to surprise its audience. When Chris and Rose hit a deer on the way to her parents, I rolled my eyes at this portentous cliché. Didn't we just see the same thing in THE INVITATION?  What makes this sequence sing, however, is the interaction they have with a police officer afterwards. Peele plays with the racism of the situation from all angles, showing us what's wrong about racial profiling while also shining a light on white privilege when Rose "sticks up" for her man.  

This awkwardness carries the film through its introductory moments very well, especially when Chris notices that all of the help on the Ermitage Estate are black.  Both the gardener (Marcus Henderson) and the housekeeper, a chillingly effective Betty Gabriel, seem a little off, yet Peele does a good job of distracting us from it by focusing on the humor provided by Rose's parents and brother, played respectively by Bradley Whitford, Catherine Keener, and Caleb Landry Jones, who I loved in THE LAST EXORCISM, but here seems to have come from a  completely different family.  While Whitford goes hilariously out of his way to appear cool to Chris, Keener's psychiatrist character uses hypnosis to get to know their guest.  

It's here where the film reveals its true agenda, and I won't spoil any of the fun.  Needless to say, the horror elements kick in, forcing Chris and Rose to make some life or death decisions.  Although the scares in the movie come mostly from shock cuts, the premise itself and the escalation of violence are enough to carry the day.  I also enjoyed the depiction of hypnosis, with cinematographer Toby Oliver's work shining in these surreal sequences.  This film really works conceptually.  It's truly original despite it pulling elements from such classics as THE STEPFORD WIVES, ROSEMARY'S BABY, and SECONDS.  What Peele has to say about race lends the film its kick.  At first, Chris finds the Ermitage's reaction to his presence amusing to the point where he feels like he has to work at making them feel ok about their ridiculousness.  When things change, his confidence erodes, with Kaluuya doing some wonderful work.

The performances across the board rule the day.  Whitford and Keener really know how to play the ambiguity to perfection, and LilRel Howery carries the lion's share of the comic relief quite capably, but its Williams who's the revelation here.  She astonishes in a phone call scene in which she stays stone-faced while vocally acting the hell out of it.  Same goes for the turn in the scene involving a search for keys.  She reminded me Nicole Kidman ease with difficult material in such films as TO DIE FOR and MALICE, perfectly balancing the simultaneous emotions.  America, we have underestimated this treasure!

Although overlong, this film has wonderful setups and payoffs, very good performances, and that rarity of rarities, something to say.  While more satirical thriller than horror, Peele, who still needs to learn to "take three things off before leaving the house", has made the first really good film of 2017.  It will surely have an interesting relationship with its audiences.  He reminds me of Melvin Van Peebles (WATERMELON MAN) in his desire to poke and provoke.  

[SPOILER ALERT]

For me, Peele duffs the ending.  While I appreciate it that he gives us the satisfaction of the black men winning, he's aiming for true subversiveness with his premise, and I thought he could have really gone further by having Chris end up in jail for all of the murders.  I can't imagine anyone believing his story and the trail of bodies all lead to him.  You may leave the theatre elated instead of fully enlightened.  

[END SPOILER]

This films' plot is mostly familiar, but the twists & turns as we watch the hero discover the truth & try to survive make for a pretty gripping watch, we even get a bit of comedy thrown in.

The cast was great, some characters were obvious villains, some took me by surprise. The hero was great, we see him go on a journey, peel back many layers of himself, & overcome obstacles, both physical, & mental. There's even a comedic sidekick, whose timing & delivery were pretty good.

The sense of dread & unease were very visceral, the fact that the hero was a black dude surrounded by white folks was irrelevant in my humble opinion, I think anyone would've felt threatened in that situation. The idea that "they" have everyone else & "you're next" is still terrifying for a reason: It. Could. Happen.

The music & sound design set the mood pretty well, only punctuating one lame jump-scare.

3 & 3/4 stars, if you love films like Body Snatchers & Stepford Wives, this one is right up your ally, & remember, just 'cause you're paranoid, doesn't mean "they" aren't out to get ya!

A fan-freaking-tastic horror/comedy. The only problems I had with it are that there are a few cheap jump scares and there is a twist that you can see coming from a mile away. Aside from that, the film is a blast.

Smart, captivating, relentlessly unsettling, and even quite funny, Get Out is a breath of fresh air from start to finish. It isn't perfect, there are a few tiny nitpicks to be had with the movie (especially on some of the goofier scare scenes in the beginning half of the movie), but it still manages to be a thrilling experience that had me and my theater roaring with applause at several moments. I'm very glad it's getting the praise and hype that it is, because at the end of the day, this a seriously solid and entertaining movie.

Get Out: Comedian Jordan Peele's directorial debut is about a young black man headed to a "meet the parents" weekend getaway with his white girlfriend. This crazy comedy/horror hybrid borrows heavily from such films as Guess Who's Coming To Dinner, The Stepford Wives, Rosemary's Baby and The Skeleton Key, and while the film is a bit too scattered to truly find its identity, it is a mindlessly entertaining, jump scare-filled ride that plays off of uncomfortable racial observations with an interesting twist - just don't think too carefully about the outrageous plot holes. Daniel Kaluuya (Sicario) and Allison Williams (HBO's Girls) both do an excellent job in their starring roles as the boyfriend/girlfriend duo. C+

An uncomfortably funny and terrifying horror film. People will talk about the film for its depiction of white urbanite racism, which is certainly the focus, but what's really clever about it is the way it layers this on top of a more typical horror plot without conflict. In fact, the plot and the subtext (if its right to call it that) actually enhance each other. Peele's said that horror and comedy are really very similar, and having seen this I have to agree with his point since the timing is perfect and every satirical laugh is balanced in such a way as to not take away from the horror. And here both horror and comedy are used to confront a very touchy issue in a way that a straight drama couldn't. It's just like Dr. Strangelove in a way: the basic problem is too horrifyingly uncomfortable to be taken seriously. Or Stepford Wives, which is really where this film draws its inspiration. Somehow the blend of uncomfortable racism and suburban horror really elevates the otherwise potentially stale material.

Blumhouse production company is a real crap shoot. In the past few years, they have put out some of the best films in recent memory and, by far, some of the worst. But when they get it good, you get "Whiplash", "Ouija: Origin of Evil" and now "Get Out". It is nice to see someone with a checkbook take chances. In this instance, they let a stand-up/sketch comedian direct a racially charged, psychological horror film, and they got a critical and box office smash. Aside from the great tension building in the hypnosis scenes that bring to mind "A Clockwork Orange", "Beyond the Black Rainbow", and "Under the Skin", it was great to see Catherine Keener take on a more sinister role. In fact, nearly the whole supporting cast are typically placed in comedic roles which helps solidify the tone and add to the feeling that something is not quite right. Director Jordan Peele obviously has a deep appreciation for horror films as the effective balance of soundtrack, comedy, and thrills culminate in a very rewarding watch. In the sold out theater I watched this in, by the third act people were reacting as one might more commonly see at a screening for a "Star Wars" movie. Cheers of approval and gasps at the twists erupted sporadically. Aside from the visceral reaction, I think there was a genuine sense of catharsis from seeing injustice combated. The blatant subtext of the film is cultural appropriation without respect. White culture has effectively harvested from Black culture for decades, yet we still see no true integration. As Black America continues to innovate and form a basis for our understanding of American culture, it continually is appropriated and made family-safe, disseminated into ubiquity without the recognition it is due. This is primarily exemplified by the music industry, but one can notice this trend in parlance and fashion as well. It is extremely interesting that Peele would take the horror genre, a form decidedly set in a rich Anglo/European/American history, and co-opt it for such a scathing social critique. It's probably one of the most effective uses of film for such purposes as I've seen in years. But if you disregard that essential aspect of it, it is pretty much your standard horror film. I'm not going to say it will change your life, but it is pretty damn entertaining and thought provoking.

After years as a brilliant sketch comedian, Get Out is Jordan Peele's first foray into horror, and if this gifted comic mind only wanted to make suspense thrillers from now on, that would be mighty fine. This is the first horror movie in years that left me buzzing, feeling charged and anxious, anxious to share with others so they too can feel the full effect of this live wire of a movie. It may be my favorite theatrical horror film since 2012's The Cabin in the Woods, and what they both have in common is a knowing understanding of their genres and expectations, a delicately balanced sense of tone, and a funhouse of darkly clever surprises. This is a movie rich with commentary, suspense, payoffs, and it all begins by exploring the dread-filled everyday existence of African-American men in this country as a waking horror movie that cannot be escaped.

Before even going further, I advise most readers to go into Get Out with as little knowledge as possible, which I understand means delaying reading this review. I can accept the loss of eyeballs knowing that more people will go in with an even greater ability to be surprised (I'll avoid significant spoilers below, so fear not, dear reader).

Chris (David Kaluuya) is visiting the parents of his girlfriend for the first time. He's worried that Rose Armitage (Allison Williams) hasn't mentioned that he's black. She assures him that her rich, wealthy, and liberal family won't care in the slightest. Rose swears her parents are the least racist people she can think of. Dean (Bradley Whitford) is a retired brain surgeon, Missy (Catherine Keener) is a hypnotherapist who volunteers to help Chris stop smoking, and Rose's younger brother, Jeremy (Caleb Landry Jones), is obsessed with martial arts and lacrosse. They also have black housekeepers, which Dean says he hates how it looks. It isn't long before Chris' sense of unease starts to make him rethink this weekend getaway and whether or not something sinister is under the surface.

Early on, Peele tips his hand to the sharp social and genre criticism. In the opening scene we watch Andrew (Lakeith Stanfield), a young black man, walking around lost in a tony suburban neighborhood. He checks his phone for an address when a lone car drives past him, stops, and turns around, pulling up next to Andrew and idling, blasting the old song "Run Rabbit Run." He takes one look at the situation and immediately turns around, heading in the opposite direction. "Not today," he says to himself, clearly providing voice to the audience's apprehension. And yet, he's incapacitated, and abducted by masked assailants. Even self-awareness and avoidance will not be enough for this man to survive if captured within the crosshairs of modern White America. He becomes another horror victim just like we might see splashed across the news all too often.

Peele's biting social commentary is ever-present but it never outpaces the genuine fun and entertainment from his genre storytelling. It's a condemnation of the fallacy of a post-racial society and an exploration of the uncomfortable burdens African-Americans are disproportionately expected to bear in general. Rose's family is all too happy to show off how seemingly inclusive they are. Rose's father confesses, with no legitimate conversational prompting, that he would have voted for Obama a third time (trust me, there's a lot of people in the camp, Dean). Yet he seems to enjoy awkwardly inserting recitations of "my man" while also trying to openly explain why he has eerily subservient black housekeepers. Rose's antic brother seems to hungrily size Chris up as a physical challenge to battle, openly admiring his "genetic gifts." Despite their self-styled liberalism and protests to the contrary that race doesn't matter, the family can't help but treat Chris like an other. Race "doesn't matter" to people who have the position where it might not matter, the same going for those who elect to be "color blind."

This stifling sense of condescension and pandering is best exemplified in a deeply awkward sequence where Chris is introduced at a party to the whole older majority-white neighborhood. One man informs him he likes Tiger Woods. Another says being black is hip. A woman squeezes his muscles in transparent lust. Another asks what the "African-American experience" is like and whether Chris feels being born black is an advantage. All through this meet-and-greet gauntlet, Chris is holding his carefully crafted smile, trying to shrug off the mounting discomfort, and being told not to make a big deal out of it. After all, these are well-educated liberals, the "good ones." They can't be racist too.

Get Out is also an excellent example of a movie that straddles a precise tone to perfection. Peele has a carefully refined comedy sensibility, but I was genuinely awed in his ability to go from sardonically funny to creepy funny to just plain creepy. There's an increasingly heightened sense of dread from the get-go. It's like any other horror premise where our protagonist goes into the house they shouldn't and combats a host of horrors be they supernatural or superhuman. In this case, the scary scenario is white people. There's a general off feeling about the Armitage estate and this is best encapsulated with their hired help, Walter (Marcus Henderson) and Georgina (Betty Gabriel). They seem to be in a robotic daze, smiles plastered to their faces, their tone of voice disquietingly calm and meticulous. Even the antiquated and culturally incongruous vocabulary they employ contributes to their unsettling vibes. Something is wrong here. There is a remarkable scene where Chris speaks with Georgina, and she hovers closer to him to apologize. Peele keeps the camera locked on his actor's faces in extreme close-ups and he has a damn good reason for it. Gabriel (The Purge: Election Year) tries to reassure him all is normal and in one mesmerizing moment the camera fixates on her as she repeats "no," each time a different reflection, her eyes tearing up as she tries to fight back subverted emotions. It's feels like you're watching twenty emotions and impulses fighting for dominance behind an impassive mask of compliance. Peele magnificently finds ways to keep his elements intensely upsetting while still finding room to laugh and break tension and increase tension.

While more a suspense thriller than a traditional horror film, Peele proves himself shockingly adept at a genre that I would have assumed outside his comfort zone. The shot arrangements and the natural development of tension shows clear knowledge and affinity for the horror genre; Peele knows when to hold onto a moment for extra suspense, when to pull back, and especially when to litter the camera frame with something to draw the eye. Peele has a great eye for his troubling, surreal visuals. When Chris is hypnotized and instructed to "sink into the floor" it's like he's falling into an inky void while his consciousness plays out on a square, like his life is a movie only he can watch from a distance. You feel the helplessness but it's also a beautiful and beautifully unnerving image. There are a few jump scares accompanied by loud musical stings but the far majority of the movie is the overwhelming discomfort and dread marvelously kept at a continual simmer. I was squirming in my seat for long stretches and started backpedaling in others, and I can't remember another movie in years affecting me that well. It's partly the terrific execution of his genre elements but also partly because I liked the protagonist and had no idea what would happen to him next, which is the foundation of all horror. The last act cranks up the genre elements but Peele has brilliantly structured his script, laying out all the pieces he'll need that provide an array of payoffs when we're breaking for the finish line. This is a movie that knows how to satisfy all audiences, rest assured.

The actors are pitch-perfect and Kaluuya (Sicario, Black Mirror) delivers a star-making performance. He has to wear his own mask to deal with the small and large iniquities of whether or not these people are sinister or whether they're just oblivious cretins. Chris is a black man expected to mind his manners and to laugh away the casual ignorance afforded by the oblivious privilege of others. He can never be unaware as the lone black man in a sea of white faces. It's a position I think many people in the audience will be able to relate to and hopefully others can empathize with. Kaluuya has some standout emotional sequences where he digs deep to show the real depth of a character others fetishize or dismiss. Kaluuya is also British and you'd never know it. The Armitage family clan are each their own slice of weird. Whitford (The Cabin in the Woods) is exploding with thinly veiled smarm and great comic awkwardness. Keener (Capote) is chilling in her icy WASP den mother role with her weapon of choice, and hypnotic aid, being a literal silver spoon. Williams is like her blithely privileged character stepped out of HBO's Girls, and her flippant attitude to Chris's perspective belies something familiar and darker. The other best actor in the movie is LilRel Howrey (The Carmichael Show) who play's a friend to Chris that works for the TSA. He's a reliable and reliable crude source of comic relief but he's also our ally on the outside, and he behaves like an intelligent investigator trying to save him. I was actually applauding his sensible steps to see through the sinister conspiracy.

It's been hours since I saw Get Out and I'm still buzzing from the experience. I was unprepared for how genuinely unnerving and invigorating the movie was as a horror thriller, character piece, but also as a trenchant social satire on race. Jordan Peele has established himself as an immediate visionary in the world of horror, taking the black protagonist who might usually be the first to get killed in a Hollywood slasher flick and widening the boundaries of horror. The real-lie horror film is day-to-day existence in the United States as a person of color. Get Out was conceived in the Obama era but has even more renewed resonance under the beginnings of the Age of Trump. I remember people saying that America now existed in a post-racial world, but we live in the kind of world that takes a call for innocent black lives to stop being executed by police officers and transforms it into All Lives Matter. It's a hazardous world and Peele has created a marvelous movie where the insidious, ever-present force that cannot be escaped is not a maniac with a chainsaw or some cranky ghost, it's white society itself. As the news has indicated, from Trayvon Martin to Sandra Bland and numerous others, there isn't exactly a safe territory to escape to. Danger and death can come at any moment as long as a larger society perceives black skin as a threat first and a person second. Get Out is a timely movie but also timeless, thanks to how brilliantly conceived, developed, and executed Peel's movie performs. This will make my top ten list for the year. Simply put, stop whatever you're doing and go out to go see Get Out as soon as possible.

First off, I want to address the significant amount of people avoiding this film labeling it "anti-white." Film is art. Thus, by definition it is a creative expression of how the creator of said art feels about himself or the environment that surrounds him or her. Therefore, if one cannot handle that, I do not know what the point is of watching anything then.

	Now, in regards to Get Out, allow me to first address the story. Get Out it is much more than a simple (and obvious) analysis of our culture and how interactions between minorities/lower social classes and predominant, high class members of society are perceived by the former. If one keeps this central theme in the back of his or her head and ventures to examine other elements of the film, it is a clear satire not only of the typical thriller genre but also of slavery, supremacism, and profiling. 
	
	For instance, take the motives behind the Armitage family's crimes. Though considering themselves as a smarter and superior people, they target African-Americans because they consider them to be "in fashion" and physically superior. One of them is even seen choosing her next target by simply using Bing to search "NCAA athletes." These situations immediately raise the question, "If people of color are treated and viewed as inferior, why then do predominant races attempt to be like them and blend in." This is a clever way to address the strong polarity America has on African-American people. It explores the idea that though some may admire people of color in Hollywood and in sports, the same people have prejudice against them depending on their socioeconomic background.

	Additionally, in a scene seen during the trailer, the protagonist is a victim of police profiling. In this scenario, the protagonist is perfectly okay with this and has his state identification ready, implying this is a social norm. Writer/Director Jordan Peele then uses this same circumstance to create a supremely clever payoff to prove to all his viewers that this truly is a sad social norm that lives within us all. I am afraid I can not give much detail as to how Peele satirizes slavery without giving away too much of the plot.

	Regardless, let's move to the technical side of Get Out. The film begins with a exceptional tracking shot. It left me confused since I thought most of the movie would be like this, which would make for an odd thriller since most rely on editing for their suspenseful effects. Evidently, I was wrong. The opening was one of a few tracking shots and the film used editing to its full advantage. However, as decent as the visual aspect of Get Out was, it does not compare to the sound. My goodness, the sound effects and mixing were incredible. Trevor Gates was the man in charge of sound mixing. He is no stranger to making us feel uncomfortable and on the edge of our seats since he was the man in charge of the sounds of Ouija: Origin of Evil and Don't Breathe. 

Overall, the film was very well made. Much better than required for the thriller genre, I may add. I would definitely recommend this movie to those in search of a thought-provoking thriller, fans of horror, or even fans of a good comedy. In regards to the story, I would only advise to keep an open mind as which any other form of art. Get Out is without a doubt a step in the right direction for first time director Jordan Peele and I cannot wait to see what he and his eye for detail have in store for us in the future.

The more I think about Get Out, the more I'm hooked. At first, I was like,  "This is supposed to be a comedy/thriller/horror flick and it doesnt do any of the genres all that amazing!" Which normally would mean a hard flop, right? ...but Peele and the surprisingly good cast of performances pile jokes on top of scares until you give up trying to figure out exactly what the film is supposed to be and sit back and enjoy one of the most entertaining and politically bold films in recent memory. The movie shows such smart control of tone (just slightly off in a good way) and pace (slow, steady). Peele has dubbed his movie a â??social thrillerâ?? and heâ??s right on the mark. Like all powerful horror and suspense films, Get Out takes everyday fears and tensions and nudges them into the freaky. Peele also knows just when and how to slacken the tension with a laugh. Get Out emerges as one of the freshest reworkings of the horror genre in years but that's mostly because itâ??s one sizzling with social commentary about race relations in America and that will be how and why it's remembered. The satire here is real, blunt and funny. There's some impressive filmmaking skills here, too. His debut feature has some memorably shocking sequences, including cool hypnotism sequences. These cinematic flourishes are layered with racial subtext regarding slavery, master race ideology and liberal guilt that weaves throughout the movie with unexpected brilliance. The shocks, laughs and suspense are all entertaining but it's the truth in the film that should make you Get Out and watch.

Who knew Jordan Peele had it in him? It's well documented throughout the anneals of history that African Americans have had it pretty shitty, and rarely do we get a glimpse into the realistic day to day eyes and emotions of those subjected to prejudice in a way that isn't heavy handed and begging for Oscar gold. "Get Out" is grounded in reality in its attempt to portray how it feels to have nothing but white eyes staring at you, and Peele brilliantly holds on to that sense of unease and judgement throughout the film. See that's the scare. There's no monster, no serials murderers with axes or chainsaw wielding cannibals, and yet the tension in this movie is far more palpable than any of those old tired horror clichÃ¨s because it's real. We know it exists. In fact, it happens every single day. "Get Out" has the impossibly self assured hands of a long-time master for a first time director, along with an absolutely rock solid script(to which he's also penned), holding onto racial tension and paranoia throughout, building to a satisfying ending for which any horror fan will appreciate. Imagine "Look Who's Coming to Dinner" had a baby with "The Stepford Wives" who had a mild fling with "Deliverance". Oh yeah, and it's pretty damn funny too. Deftly crafted and balanced in both giggles and gore, this is one of the better pictures in the genre since the brilliant "It Follows". It seems horror is being lifted from the exploitative dumps of the five dollar DVD bin and back to the top shelf, and the movie going world is better for it.

Get Out movie review (NO SPOILERS):  Jordan Peele (of Key and Peele fame) needs to take a bow. Because he's about to get a LOT of attention.  This movie was fantastic.  It manages to have the same creepy, unnerving dread of classic horror/thrillers you (and obviously Peele himself) grew up loving while still feeling fresh and particularly relevant today.  This is not just your standard fare. This movie actually has something to say. 

It's successful not just because it's wonderfully crafted, but also because of the sometimes subtle, yet biting and wholely relevant social commentary which runs throughout the film.  This manner in which this is presented serves to bond the audience to its lead character and allows us a perspective, while immediately engaging, most genre films would shy away from. 

Peele's choice of his protagonist and the perspective he's allowing us in on is not the only reason this works. The film is exceptionally well cast and features some of the finest acting I've seen in years.  In particular, Daniel Kaluuya, who's work in the lead role as Chris, is bound to get him some serious looks.  Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener as the parents have never been better, and Betty Gabriel turns in a supremely creepy performance as Georgina.  I could list every cast member here as they all had their moments and there were no flat, throwaway characters. Everything served the story. 

One of the reasons this film was so satisfying was the work of Chris's best friend played by Lil Rel Howery.  Not only did he provide much needed comic relief throughout a tense and taught thriller, but very much served as the voice of the audience.  He stole every scene he was in. 

To sum up,  this is a beautifully crafted  movie and it's hard  to believe it's Peele's directorial debut. I will watch this again and again and can't wait to see what he does next. Go see it!

I've seen many Horror films over the years. A lot of them look very much like each other. Most of these films are veeeery generic in formula or are just not executed right. We have long since been removed from the days of legendary slasher films and went through many years of found footage style films that have almost all been duds. Now, of all the people to give us a brand new fresh horror film, it is none other than one half of comedy duo Key and Peele, Jordan Peele. Peele gives us a horror film like no other, one that deals with the subject of racism. Get Out is of the more creative and uniquely executed stories for this genre and it is very suprising.
	Get Out is about Chris, a black photographer and his white girlfriend Rose. The two of them are going up to rose's parents house for the weekend. Chris meets her parents and the inhabitants of their area that all exhibit bizarre unusual behavior. It doesn't take long for Chris to be freaked out and he later discovers a dark secret about the family.
	A very solid unique film. It actually transcends a bit beyond horror and is more of a racial satire.I initially went in thinking Jordan Peele was going to just hammer in statements about racism when it comes to interacial interactions. He actually instead utilizes more of the uncomfortable and tense atmosphere when black people are surrounded by folks who act a certain way based on the color of your skin to make his point. A brilliant directorial choice that served him well this entire film. 
the film had some great humorous moments that you don't often see in horror films. good cinematography and good editing as well. 
Alison Williams and Daniel kaluuya were both excellent especially Kaluuya in his first real film role. Their facial expressions body language and even their ability to disappear into the world of the characters was nice to watch and very impressive. Bradley Whitford did a fine job here. He provided a nice blend of being mysterious and unsettling in nature. One of his best roles since his days on the west wing.Even Catherine Keener did well here. She played one of the real key roles in this film than the trailer leads on. 
Overall 2 thumbs way up and I must say I am looking forward to more films directed by Mr. Peele

The film was so well-done! I left the theatre still feeling the emotions of the main character. A few older white ladies walked past me in the restroom and I had flutters of panic before remembering that I am also a white woman. 

I do wonder about the gravity of emotion that will experienced by black people. I can't fully tap into the existential fear that Peele hit on in this movie. I can understand it but it's a depth I simply can't reach from my personal experience. So I wonder if it won't also be kind of triggering for some.

I wish more horror films were as relevant and smart as Get Out. The movie feeds off a paranoia that the majority of the United States population doesn't experience on a regular basis. Fake smiles and awkward handling of racially charged conversations are masterfully put on display in the first half of the movie. The cracks in the white facade intensify at a steady pace. Uncomfortable questions or points start popping up in the viewer's mind. What is up with the eclectic decor (explicitly called out)? Why are all the black "caretakers" acting "white" on the property? Are we, as white people, really this ignorant? In short, you start to feel an entire system is out to get our protagonist. Admittedly, an early scene explicitly sets the stage up. Mainstream horror films play it safe with the usual jump scares and gory imagery. To be sure, Get Out sports a fair amount of both elements. At some point, all too shockingly familiar racism starts to out scare the traditional horror cliches. Unfortunately, several dumb horror tropes also make an appearance. For example, you have that one horror scene where you have an odd figure chopping wood. The others tropes I could list involve spoilers. The acting is consistently top notch from all involved. I only have one minor quip with the casting choice of a peripheral character. The character certainly sticks out when you notice him and the inclusion is somewhat puzzling. Overall, the subject matter more than makes up for Get Out's very minor shortcomings. How often do movies aimed at a mainstream audience have the audacity to call out whites in America? The timing of the film's release is sadly impeccable. Racism is alive and well in our country. America "smiled" when she elected Trump as POTUS. I congratulate Jordan Peele for his impressive foray into directing. The film is dense and I certainly missed a few points on my first viewing.

"Get Out" is the rare horror/mystery/thriller that works almost entirely due to a tense atmosphere and shocking moments that will creep you out. It relies on very few jump scares and actually just maintains a scary vibe without them. I was invested in this movie from the moment it started. I felt it was wholly original and endlessly creative. It's the type of movie that I want to watch again to analyze and look for hints I missed the first time. I was consistently wondering how this movie was going to end and was truly surprised by how it ended. I also found myself laughing a lot since there is a comedic relief character that never feels forced. I think the movie is somewhat over the top in places and has a couple moments that are paced a bit slower than the rest. Regardless, the finale of this movie is insanely entertaining and keeps you on the edge of your seat. The movie also has a lot of social commentary going for it, which made it even more unique. It's a movie that defies genre conventions and is most definitely worth seeing. Jordan Peele is a surprisingly phenomenal filmmaker and I wouldn't be surprised if he took some time off from sketch comedy to make more movies like this.

There have been few Horror films this past decade that have redefined the genre. "You're Next" dissected the slasher subgenre, while "The Cabin In the Woods" poked fun and payed homage to Horror in a thought provoking blend. "Get Out" is on the exact same level, if not a step above them. Jordan Peele proves that Comedy is not the only area in film he can succeed in (Key & Peele). This is a truly interesting and original concept which turns racial stereotyping and modern day racism into an extremely strong social commentary. Like Peele has done in the past, there are flat out hilarious moments in "Get Out" that make it damn near impossible not to enjoy it even if the film comes across as too "bizarre" for non horror fans. Avoiding major spoilers, this is an important and incredibly well conceived concept that blends multiple genres together while pulling apart what today's world defines as prejudices and racist thinking both from a black/white perspective. It's just disappointing that some less open minded people will leave the theatre not appreciating the true meaning behind the film. One of the best Horror/Comedies of all time and a must see for those looking for something new. It's very rarely I'll rate a movie a perfect score. On another note, this film has possibly the most hilarious character I've seen in a long while (The TSA friend).

Proper Perspective: This movie is not going to reinvent the wheel in the horror genre, but it also doesn't break or hinder the wheel. More of a mystery-thriller with elements of horror sprinkled in throughout...

Official Synopsis: A young African-American man visits his Caucasian girlfriend's mysterious family estate.

Plot: When Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) and Rose (Allison Williams) go on a "meet the parents" trip to Rose's family home out in a remote location, things get weird. Initially it appears to be the awkwardness of parents meeting the boyfriend, who also happens to be a different race than them, but slowly devolves into what appears to be tests, or racism, or attacks, and at an annual family party everything comes to a head.

Take: Like I already mentioned, this movie does not reinvent the wheel. It is a social commentary on racism today, the subtleties and the obviousness. There is some of The Stepford Wives vibes initially, then it turns into a mystery and psychological thriller. Who is doing what? What should we believe? What is happening???

The movie did a good job of dropping bread crumbs along the way for the audience, but not the entire loaf. As you watch you can piece together where they are going, not in a bad way. This movie is like piecing a puzzle together, sort of knowing the final picture, but the surprise at the end is still worth the journey.

I really liked the overall story, acting, and direction of this movie. It is Jordan Peele's first feature directorial effort. The movie was also written by Peele, who has also written on MadTV, Key and Peele, and last year's Keanu. He has a knack for character and story, peppering in the jokes to lighten the mood and keep the viewer off balance.
The jokes were too much at times, but this style can work in horror where tension is released with a fun character gag.

To compare this to another directorial debut, say last year's "Morgan" from Luke Scott (Ridley Scott's son), this is a better overall film.

The rest of the cast is rounded out by Lakeith Stanfield (Short Term 12, Straight Outta Compton), Catherine Keener (40 Year Old Virgin), Bradley Whitford (The Cabin in the Woods, West Wing), Caleb Landry Jones (X-Men: First Class), and Lilrel Howery (The Carmichael Show). The cast played well of each other and nobody felt out of their depth.

Recommendation: In a year, that is not quite two months in, we have two very good thriller/horror movies in Split and now Get Out. I'd recommend going out to support this film if you are one that clamors for original movies and less sequels, remakes, reboots, etc...

Get Out is the directorial debut of Jordan Peele who you might recognize from the sketch comedy show, Key & Peele. Get Out is not a comedy though it contains a fair amount of laughs, namely from the performance of stand-up comedian LilRel Howery who will get many, many jobs from this star-making performance. What Get Out actually turns out to be is a rather striking thriller that provides a topical conversation around racial tensions that then amplifies and exaggerates the inherent tensions of its presented scenario in a way that both plays with the tropes of the horror genre while delivering commentary on innate and unavoidable fears in the black community. I heard someone explain it as, "playing on black people's fear of white people's fear of black people," and it's hard to put it any better or more simply than that. This is all to get to the point that Get Out is making the point that we need to stop pretending we know what it's like to walk in other people's shoes. Not that these assumptions can't be compassionate, but more that they are unnecessary. Get Out begins as one thing-playing on the natural awkwardness that comes along with a black guy going to meet his white girlfriends entirely white family in their very white/suburban neighborhood for the first time and then, once it arrives there, takes steps using its genre classification to get at this idea that no matter how good or well-intentioned one might be, it is near impossible to have a real comprehension of what people who have experienced struggles and/or faced some kind of oppression have indeed been through and more over, who they became out of such experiences. Get Out is a film that plays on those facets of ourselves that we'd rather not acknowledge-that no matter how much we believe ourselves to be above stereotyping people or forming preconceptions, that there is a truth to such ways of thinking and Peele uses this unavoidable, unflattering truth to draw out a fair amount of anxiety. Peele plays on those anxieties and social standards exceptionally as through to the very last frame Get Out keeps things as taut as any horror movie in recent memory while never losing sight of its original intent no matter how crazy the genre hijinks get.

GET OUT
Director/Writer: Jordan Peele
Starring: Daniel Kaluuya, Allison Williams, Bradley Whitford, Catherine Keener, Lakeith Stanfield, Lil Rel Howery, Stephen Root, Marcus Henderson, Betty Gabriel

I would never have thought funnyman Jordan Peele would have turned to the horror genre for his directorial debut. He's best known as one half of the Comedy Central duo Key and Peele. After their show ended, they released the cat action comedy Keanu last year, and now Peele is flying solo. There's that old myth that the black guy always dies in a scary movie, and Peele is shifting that around with Get Out. Girls star Allison Williams stars as Rose Armitage who is excited to take her boyfriend, Chris (Kaluuya), home to meet her parents and brother. He feels a bit worried, as she hasn't broken the news to them that she's dating a black man. Rose doesn't feel a concern in the world as she states they are extremely welcoming and that her dad, Dean (Whitford), would have voted for Obama a third time. Rose's parents have a picture perfect estate nestled in the woods. Dean is a bit abrasive to Chris at first, while her mom, Missy (Keener), is quieter and introspective. She's basically studying his demeanor and behavior due to her work as a psychiatrist and hypnotist. Chris happens to notice that they have a maid and a groundskeeper who both happen to be black.

Rose tries to remind him that it will be a lovely weekend, but he has his guard up. There's something off about the maid and groundskeeper. They appear to be doing their jobs, but they have a wide-eyed, zombie-like disposition where they're not all together with it. The weekend carries on with the Armitage family hosting an outdoor party. All of the guests are white, rich, and lavish. The sole black partygoer is around Chris's age and also appears to be in this alternative state of mind. Chris can't help shake that there is something deeply wrong with this family and their friends. His best friend, Rod (Howery), works as a TSA agent and starts to dig deeper into this mystery when Chris finds himself trapped in the Armitage's house.

Within the opening sequence, you can easily tell that Jordan Peele has a knack for directing horror. It opens in that dark and quiet suburban neighborhood. It was very reminiscent of Halloween in that sense, including the use of hedges. It's very suspenseful and eerie without relying on cheap tricks. It sets the stage for what's to come as it shifts to the introduction of Rose and Chris's relationship. Peele takes his time with a nice build up with the characters and the relationship within the family. He remembers that in order for scary movies to be effective you have to care about the characters. He gives it that slow burn effect as the suspenseful moments build up to a grand finale. So much of the movie relies on Chris's growing suspicion, and Peele knows how to keep him teetering on the edge of sanity. I never felt like it was pummeled with obnoxious jump scares or blood and guts as a way of being scary. Betty Gabriel and Marcus Henderson are creepy enough as the maid and groundskeeper, respectively. They have some evil death stares while keeping a Pollyanna grin on their face at times.

What you normally don't find in horror films, especially of late, is a social commentary. Jordan Peele adds a fair amount of racial dialogue and satire in the film when Chris realizes the mental state and behavior of the other black characters in juxtaposition of the extremely privileged white community present. As the dad, Bradley Whitford tries to acknowledge it but passes it off as pure irony. The party guests all have a certain "reaffirming" way of speaking to Chris where think they're being polite, but it's all comes out incorrectly. Race isn't the only hot topic as I felt a connection to Scientology given Catherine Keener's profession as a psychiatrist and hypnotist. Not to get too spoilery here but brain washing comes into play with Kenner going into the subconscious of Chris's mind.

The films boasts a perfectly cast family. Williams is not nearly as annoying as her Girls character Marnie can be. Whitford and Keener are clearly having a barrel of fun as Mom and Dad. This is the first time I've seen British actor Daniel Kaluuya, and he can easily pull of the paranoid aspects of Chris. Jordan Peele doesn't fully drop his comedic side and cast Lil Rel Howery in the comedic sidekick role of the film. Howerey brings out just enough laughs at the expense of what's going on with the situation and how seriously he takes his job as a TSA agent.

Get Out is impressive move for Jordan Peele has he continues on in his post Key and Peele career. I've already seen two pathetic genre movies this year with The Bye Bye Man and Rings. Peele stays clear of their issues as he's a smart writer and doesn't try too hard to make it scary. There are pacing issues that become evident with its slow burn nature. This will no doubt become an issue in the current age where scary movies need to move at lightning speed. I can only assume Peele will work on this as his directing career takes off. He's written in some good laughs like I mentioned earlier, but the balance between laughter and screams isn't as consistent as it is in films like Scream and Shaun of the Dead. The film comes with that third act twist that is often found smart horror movies. It makes sense if you're putting the puzzle pieces together like Chris is. By the end, the audience was cheering and applauding. That certainly didn't happen with Rings. I'm looking forward to seeing Jordan Peele take on these genre-bending types of movies. I'll gladly sign up for more funny-scary movies from him.

Is It Worth Your Trip to the Movies? Horror fans looking for something fresh and exciting will get a kick out of Get Out.

Jordan Peele directorial debut has shattered horror film ceilings, in the intoxicating and wildly captivating Get Out. What makes Get Out truly cutting edge in horror is the fact that it echoes an existing fear that many black individuals, who reside in a predominantly white society, face. It perfectly encapsulates the quiet apprehension that lies under the surface when initially meeting a non-black stranger; the fear of whiteness as an assertion of power. The inherent violence of whiteness, as a political identity, is something that many previous horror flick directors have dabbled with (see Kevin Smith's 'Red State') but have never tackled with such transparency and vigor. Peele sets himself apart by daring to take it to the deepest darkest corners of our bigotry

I've been a fan of Jordan Peele since season one of Key & Peele, even in that show you could tell that the team had an immense talent to recreate the tones and tropes of those that they were parodying. I loved Keanu and thought that the trailer for Get Out looked really interesting so I had to check it out. I had a blast in the theater with a pretty engaged audience and a fun crowd, the direction is impeccable, the performances are awesome and the film overall was a great original concept.

However, leaving the theater I tried to think back to just one white person who wasn't evil in the movie and I couldn't think of any. I would've felt better if there was even one regular white dude for comedy relief to comment on how crazy the town was, but nope. That seemed like a kind of mean-spirited and unnecessarily divisive depiction, especially in the world we live in right now. The last thing we need is more narrative trying to get us to fear each other for no reason which was the opposite of what was happening in the theater where everyone was enjoying themselves regardless. I love the movie, love Jordan, the message less so, but it's a fun flick in the end, just not necessarily for everybody, Get Out gets a 4 out of 5 out of me.

Jordan Peele's feature directorial debut is a clever horror comedy that makes up for an underwritten script by exhibiting some really effective genre filmmaking. Seemingly modeled off of past suburban-allegory horror films (perhaps most namely The Burbs), Get Out definitely feels like a throwback picture, but its thematic material regarding race is more timely than ever. Peele has proven to have an auteur's eye in many of the sketches he directed, and his transition to cinema is often impressive. He gives viewers plenty of great bits of gore and viscera, and keeps the pacing interesting so that horror fans shouldn't be (too) bummed that the killings don't come to the film's last act. Unfortunately though, Peele's talents as a writer are less evident in this picture. While it's filled to the brim with good ideas, most of them aren't explored to their full potential, and the ending feels a bit rushed as our hero seems to get out a bit too conveniently. Still, Get Out is certain to be a crowd pleaser for its target audience, and if Peele were open to explore more of the film's mythology for a sequel than I would be open for it.

Get Out Movie Review
A riveting trailer with answers practically written all over it, the beginning of the film being so predictable you begin to question its predictability, when in fact it is that predictable. When the film reaches its climax stage it all unfolds, the "mystery" we have all been waiting to be unveiled... Why is it so obvious and an even more important question is; why was I still so engaged up until the end? Now a film cannot be scrutinized for its predictability, if it reaches the stage where it is predictable to the point you don't care what happens next, that's where you should have a problem, but what is so different with Get Out? Why are the cliché's so exhilarating?
Character Development is such a huge factor in film, the absence of it in this movie makes the narrative, the plot and the message so much more interesting. The deer getting killed, Chris' identification with it and embodiment of it, the racial profiling from the police officer, all this veered the audience into the message of "White people dislike Black people" when in fact it is nothing of the sort. The film attacks the idea that there is such a difference between Black and White people, it simply states yes we have different minds and intuition, we are each enhanced in our own way but by no means are we different as people, as a society.
Now besides the clear racial messages this film utters it possesses lots of cliché's, the protagonists heroic and merciless resurgence, the ever so satisfying death to all rampage which makes any supporter in the audience yell "Yes!" behind the grit of their teeth. The female protagonists sudden turn to antagonist and complete transformation of character, this brings us back to the lack of character development, as to say yes she changed completely right at the end; suddenly tying her hair in a ponytail, but did we ever know her? I certainly didn't gasp when she turned, whether predictable or not she never truly had an identity. This applies to Chris as well, his immediate concern of her parents knowing that he is Black, as to say the people who are concerned with the differences of Blacks and Whites are the people who lack any character themselves as they restrict themselves from... Well, themselves.
I think this film has many layers, too many for me to be bothered to try and analyze, and had tons of depth in the story, the pacing was great, the acting was fantastic and the directing performance was brilliant. This is a great thriller, it won't blow you away with plot-twists but it will keep you on the edge of your seat feeding you more information which you thought you predicted, but you actually did predict it, then thought it couldn't be that predictable, but it actually was that predictable, but then turns out it wasn't, no wait it actually was.

*this review contains spoilers

Lives up to the buzz, although if I had managed to avoid the buzz I think the film would have come as much more of a surprise. 

What is great about Peele's choice of direction is that he manages to take a serious issue (racism), normally the subject of either (satire) comedy or serious drama, and set it within a genre that fuses these two things together in a wonderful and unexpected social commentary. Actually, I am surprised that the horror genre hasn't really tackled the subject in the past, as it really is perfect for bringing to light a discussion of the underlining fears that guide the issue in both past and present (which is really what horror, in general, does so well, is take a familiar issue of our day and use it to confront our fears and our questions surrounding the issue). 

Right from the start, I was able to recognize Peele's interest in playing with some familiar horror movie (and other genre movies) tropes. For example the opening scene, which shows a black man getting killed is juxtaposed with the young, white girl getting killed in the end. It is almost easy to miss the fact that he is playing with the idea (or fact) that horror films typically open with a young, white girl being the first to get killed. It's subtle, but it actually sets the tone for the film to make a strong social statement about our stereotypes, tendencies and neighbourhood. It is also no mistake that the film makes its lead a black man living in a suburban neighbourhood, given that the normal setting for a hollywood horror is setting the white person in an urban (inner city) neighbourhood. In doing this it forces us to re-examine the nature of our fear and how it is being displayed on-screen. 

And this is really where the film gets interesting. Again, in strong spoiler territory, the whole premise of the film as it eventually veers into almost science fiction territory, brings out the image of the black experience being one of feeling stuck in their own skin without a voice. Unable to speak and express themselves even though they can see what is going on around them. It is a powerful symbol that Peele unveils with a strong creative force. This is not your basic horror story, even though, in many respects, it feels like that is exactly what it sets out to be. 

I love the way the film takes a singular experience that many of us (who are not black) could not truly understand (of being the only black man in the room), and weaves it into a story that we can empathize with and recognize from our own experience (for example, as a white, caucasian male). And the truth is, recognizing this story from the perspective of a white male was incredibly uncomfortable and revealing. And it should be. I recognize that I am associated with much of the incredibly shameful, and even sometimes subtle (but no less harmful) racism that the film exposes. Not that I believe I am racist (I chose to stand against all forms of it), but that my actions can certainly still be unintentionally racist, whether I know it or not. And it is helpful to be aware of this. 

What is even more interesting is the films over arching metaphors (which shed light on the kind of extreme white supremacy that seemed to be resurfacing during Trumps recent campaign) really give way to those subtleties as the more important conversation for everyday life in our modern day. We can recognize extremism, and most of us would disagree with it, but we don't always see those subtleties. The film reminds us that in much of American (North American) history, blacks were not only treated like commodities, but in many ways they were also feared, largely by those who thought they would (and could) overpower the dominant white population of the time. And fear can cause us to do and think some pretty terrible things sometimes. And what makes Get Out perhaps most scary of all, most horrifying, is that some of these fears still exist, even if they look a little bit different or less obvious. To this end Peele has done us all a favour by shedding a welcome light on the black experience.

I mean, come on, after this beautiful premise, even innovative for a genre, you resolve all this in a bloody one-sided act of vengeance which delivers nothing, actually, no thrill at all, it's predictable with its each step.
Another beautiful thing about this movie that it's multilayered. It could be interpreted differently. The 2nd best movie I have seen in 2017 so far.  This movie touches on the topic of race in the post-Obama age tactfully and in a way that leaves you laughing and in suspense often times simultaneously. The script could have satisfied viewers as a suspense film alone but the added value of using this platform to make a metaphor that about race habits being just as suspenseful as a horror movie to those living the African American experience cannot be measured.   The subtle (yet to many of us... not so subtle) symbolic images and coded dialogue give this movie layers that after only one viewing one cannot decipher without the discussions one will have with friends and relatives. Jordan Peele's directorial debut is an exhilarating horror thriller that also manages to spark laughter and comment on social issues. The cinematography, tropes, and soundtrack echo horror, but the film finds abundant moments of comic relief like when a father reassures the main character he isn't racist by claiming, "I would have voted for Obama for a third term." Before the plot delves into a traditional horror frenzy, it mines the horrors of racism. The social commentary plays on audience expectations and results in both humor and suspense. Delivering both on the expectations of the genre and the comedic expectations of a Jordan Peele creation, GET OUT is simply amazing.

Get Out is a smart and unique horror film from director Jordan Peele. I really liked the performances in this film. Daniel Kaluuya is great in the lead role. Allison Williams, Bradley Whitford, and Catherine Keener are all good in their supporting roles. Lil Rel Howery is a standout as the best friend and the comic relief in the film. The film is very unique. It is funny, yet eerie. It balanced the tone nicely. The film isn't particularly scary, but has nice thrills towards as the end of the film. The film has a lot of slow buildup that leads to a thrilling finale. I liked how writer-director Jordan Peele weaved social commentary into an entertaining horror film. Overall, while the film isn't scary, it is smart and effective. It is a one of a kind and unique film that you should definitely check out.

I wouldn't really characterize this as a horror movie, it's more of a psychological thriller. What happens when a pretty young white girl brings her handsome new boyfriend home to meet the very well-to-do family who live clear out in the remote suburbs.., oh yeah, she hasn't told them yet that he just happens to be a black man. As you can well imagine, awkward moments start to unravel to the point of uncomfortableness. This is a new take on some other movies of the genre. I enjoyed the humorous moments that are tossed in at times to cut the tension. I think that it will do quite well at the box office.

Get Out is as close to perfection as any movie is going to get! The music was really good too, it added to the suspense in a good way. The finale was by far the best part of any movie I have seen this year, great acting, great twists and everything makes sense! I have seen so many movies where nothing makes sense but Peele did a good job making sure all the pieces of the puzzle fit. 

Overall Get Out is a creepy movie with great jokes, fantastic acting and an amazing director who knows what he is doing!

This is an illustration on racism from both sides of the spectrum based on preconceived opinions. The judgement that this film is "white people are evil propaganda" on behalf of a white or a black/brown/tan/yellow person is exactly what makes this film a piece of genius material. 

This is indeed a suspense thriller though not necessarily scarily. Milton "Lil Rey" Howery, who plays the leads cousin, is a show stealer. This guy is so funny! I laughed before he could get his full sentences out.

As much as critics drooled over this film, it was on account of their emotional approach to movies, and for that reason only, that this film received a 99%. This film is merely great, but not excellent, because it does not build suspense like the other horror flicks, but builds fear and unnerving feels for the audience as a result of the cringe worthy race card that is played throughout the movie. It is great because of the outstanding acting performances by Daniel Kaluuya and Allison Williams. BUT! It does not have a very culminating and overwhelming climax, and it would seem that Daniel Kaluuya's Chris got out way to easy. It was basically a joke that the white people who captured him actually believed that they could keep him there. Not to mention the light innuendo of racism that Jordan Peele had in mind when screenwriting. But not towards blacks, but towards whites. By showing that black people like Chris are constantly humiliated by white racism, he is making middle class white liberals out to be the bad people. Since Chris also only socializes to the black groundskeeper and black housemaid, Peele is clearly trying to introduce the feel of segregation not only in this movie, but in this world overall. Great horror, humor, and acting, but terrible theme, interpretation, and opinion of African American victimization.

Get Out - I genuinely had no idea what to expect with this one. It's a horror movie, but it's written and directed by one of the Key & Peele guys. And I'm not gonna lie, I thought it might end up being a white-bashing couple of hours based on one of the trailers. But it turned out to be a very solid horror flick.
The main actor, Daniel Kaluuya, I had only seen on the English show Black Mirror (which is incredible by the way) so seeing him in this type of American role was quite a shift. He does extraordinarily well, showing a wide range of different emotions. And finally I can report that an accent was done well! I never heard him drop out of it.
Race definitely plays a big role, but it's not presented in a vicious way. It more just shows the constant foot-in-mouth moments of white people when they're around African Americans. Rather than a hateful approach to the divide, it takes an honest route and pokes fun at it. The movie's theme and underlying story of course go deeper than this, showing the first time director's ability to get this across without just having the white people shouting the n word to show us they're the villains.
A smart, creepy, and satisfying social commentary. 8/10.

Get Out

An African-American man accompanies his Caucasian girlfriend on a trip to visit her seemingly normal family.

Written and directed by Jordan Peele, Get Out is a horror/mystery/thriller encasing a racial/societal satire with well timed moments of humor...and it's brilliant. A slow-burn pace unfolds this story a tiny morsel at a time until the bone chilling reveal. A modern-day Hitchcockian gem. 

Grade:  A

'Get Out' certainly has an interesting premise, and some great performances to go along with it. For the first half it's a genuinely creepy, frightening idea that made for some tense viewing. Some aspects of the plot are quite clever, with little details coming to fruition later on and making a lot more sense. However, about two thirds of the way through, the movie went from interesting to completely bonkers. There's a revelation involving brain surgery that...well, it's a little bit too ridiculous, and made it difficult to take the film seriously from that point on. It's certainly an entertaining twist, but it did rather go against the tone the rest of the movie had set. Some of the dialogue, too, feels a little stilted at times and the pacing is a bit uneven - but it's ultimately that final act that will either make or break your opinion of Jordan Peele's ambitious debut. For me, I'm still not sure.

If you told me that Jordan Peele of Key & Peele, a pretty popular sketch comedy show would make a hybrid satire/comedy/horror and would all blend together well, I would be in disbelief. Well luckily, Get Out succeeds at blending these elements will to bring tension through the 103 minute runtime.
Daniel Kaluuya as Chris plays a mid 20s photographer going to meet his girlfriend Rose's family for the weekend, but quickly realizes he becomes increasingly uncomfortable with the questions Rose's family asks him and he begins to discover even more.
Where this film succeeds is playing in the racial undertones in a not over the top way. It lends itself that much more to the tension Chris feels when he finds out why he's truly here (don't worry I won't spoil it). There are a handful of scares, but get easily settled with great laughs, particularly Lil Rel Howery as Rod who delivers a handful of the biggest laughs in the movie.
Some will say Get Out has a "agenda", but at its core, it's a successful thriller that never once falls off nor loses track of its goal and I'm hoping we see more films by Jordan Peele.

One of the smartest, most unnerving, and deeply satisfying horror movies I have ever seen. Trust me when I tell you that this movie is full of surprises and the trailers don't give away anything. It wastes no time in getting really weird, and ratchets up the tension every step of the way. The way the mystery unfolds and the pacing and timing of the reveals is expertly done. First time director Jordan Peele nails the genre and flips it on its head, using comedy sparingly - but at the most perfect moments to cut the tension. It's unique in its portrayal of the black experience and its commentary on underlying liberal racism and how it manifests itself. It's the kind of movie that causes outbursts of laughter and exclamation and applause, and seeing it in a crowded theater only enhanced that participatory experience. I was semi-skeptical going into this because I knew so little about it, but it ended up being one of the most surprising movies I've seen in recent memory. It definitely lives up to its 99% on Rotten Tomatoes - and fuck that one asshole critic that gave it a bad review just to bring it down from 100. This is damn near perfect.

Wait, did I see Jordan Peele's name attached to this horror movie as the director? Yes, yes I did. Get Out marks the famous comedian's directorial debut in the form of an interesting take on the horror-thriller genre. And it's a debut that pays off immensely.

For those that have seen the trailers for Get Out, you know that it focuses on a young couple consisting of a black man and a white woman as they venture out for a weekend trip to meet her parents. After they arrive, the young black man, Chris, played by Daniel Kaluuya, feels uncomfortable in the primarily white environment of her parents' household, and even more uncomfortable as strange things begin to happen in the house. Those strange things quickly become sinister, and Chris is forced into a terrifying fight for his life as he tries to "get out." Now, some of the biggest standouts of the film are the performances, particularly that of the little-known Kaluuya and several of the main supporting actors (like Catherine Keener and Bradley Whitford, who play the parents, Allison Williams, who plays his girlfriend rose, and Betty Gabriel, who plays their black maid Georgina). All of these performances contribute to a genuinely creepy and unnerving atmosphere set up during the first half of the film. The way the film executes Chris' uncomfortable predicament of being a black man in a sea of white folk is brilliant, making us as an audience feel genuinely unsettled. It almost does not even need the more traditional horror-film aspects, like jump scares and creepy music, to create this atmosphere. It is marvelously well-done, making the majority of the first half of the film tense and freaky. As the secrets and events of the plot begin to unfold over the course of the film, the creepy and unsettling tone gives way to a much more intense thrill-ride, one that is, again, executed fantastically. Many of the shots induce audible reactions, nail-biting tension, and applause-worthy relief, giving way to a satisfying ending to a satisfying film.

Get Out, in short, works as both a social commentary on situations like the one Chris is in and an excellent horror-thriller film. Some other note-worthy things to mention are the comedy sprinkled throughout the dialogue that helps relieve some of the unsettling feelings I had. The cinematography was another praiseworthy aspect of the film: shaky-cam was utilized effectively on occasion, and there were many beautiful shots especially near the beginning of the film that provided great additions to the set-up. But anyway, Get Out is a fantastic horror-thriller film and a promising step in Peele's career as a filmmaker. It gets 5/5 stars.

Definitely not your run-of-the-mill horror flick, but one that has the stamp of Jordan Peele all over it. At first I had no idea how the comedy and horror would interweave, but I see it's akin to Zombieland (2009) - the premise is ludicrous and there are comedic moments (Rod!), but the movie itself remains scary.

Speaking of - 'Get Out' is unnerving and chilling in that, at its heart, it is a dramatic social commentary. However, it's not exactly terrifying and perhaps is best described as a psychological thriller than a true horror film.

It remains, however, pretty entertaining (Rod!) and takes you on a bewildering ride that is sure to get you to react, somehow. Sure, the music might not be the best (despite the horror genre seemingly relying on cheesy SFX) and even too overt, but Peele has done an incredible job of creating an ever-escalating experience with a smaller budget.

Definitely worth a try.

Edit: Increased for its rewatch value. The detail to filler ratio in this is incredible.

The fear of meeting the significant others parents has always been an anxiety of wondering how they are like. The anxiety of trying to impress them, the background history or even the appearance can make you feel a little nervous. Director/writer Jordan Peele first film and tackling a horror genre at that makes a pretty entertaining movie. He definitely has his work cut out as a director by making the one thing couples usually have an anxiety about and twisting it around.

The film follows Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) and his girlfriend Rose (Allison Williams) are planning a small trip to visit her parents. He is afraid they will judge him for being a black guy. They arrive at their country side house, were Chris notices that there is a black guy doing work on their yard or a house maid. Which her parents assure him that they are not prejudice. When his girlfriends mother does an hypnosis session with him. He notices that everyone there may not be who they say they are.

Get Out is a great suspenseful horror movie. It may not be scary or bloody. It does build the mystery suspense. The moments of Chris noticing the strange behaviors that the house maids are behaving. Her parents behaviors being erratic and cheery and creepy about meeting him and introducing him to other guests in a big party. The concept of hypnosis is also pretty crazy as Chris starts questioning if its his paranoia self about fearing about being judged for his race or if something sinister is going on. Jordan Peele does well building the suspense and the anxiety with a white family having black people as maids.

I was very surprised about how awesome this movie was. I had low expectations after watching the trailers and was thinking it would be a cheesy bad acting horror movie. Jordan Peele proved the expectations wrong. It turned out to be a smart suspenseful movie were you root for the main character. Which is rare to see characters make certain decisions which can be frustrating in most horror movies.

There is a twist that is best not to reveal or talk about. The less you know or see from the previews the better the surprise will be. The last act and the ending does not disappoint. The movie does have some funny moments and plus a comic relief character that is Chris friend that is always throwing jokes about sex slaves and only trusting the "brothers" of his kind.

Daniel Kaluuya did great which this is my first time seeing him perform on screen. Allison Williams did well as his girlfriend. Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener both were great and creepy with their characters.

Once the twist is revealed, it can be kind of disturbing about whats really going on. Without giving much away. Overall, Get Out is a great horror film. Director Jordan Peele may have a great start working on films. The suspense and funny moments were well balanced. The twist was surprising. The cast and acting were great. The plot and concept of interracial meeting the family and paranoia was entertaining. I definitely recommend the film if you are looking for suspense
