Originally appealing because of its racial theming, I went to see this out of curiosity because it received good reviews, was a popular topic between me and my Chinese friend, and it also appeared quite original. Aside from having many stereotypical talking points, this was really quite a unique horror, unpredictable, humorous, vaguely gruesome in parts and perfectly staged into a climatic ending. Ultimately it's about a girl introducing her new boyfriend to her parents, and you sense that the film is going to be about them turning against him because he's black. This isn't the case though, so that part is cleverly deceiving, and hides the truer meaning of the storyline. Horrors are normally so obvious and littered with cliche's, but you're left feeling dumb when you realise this film has actually made a fool of its audience in producing a twist ending that no one saw coming. It teases us into knowing there are some strange goings on, yet never revealing the full identity of proceedings until the closing moments. At which point, you leave the cinema on an all time high, applauding the producers for their cunning plot. It has a few jumpy moments which you try to play cool, but fail ridiculously, a new looking but very professionally acted cast, and the odd look away scene where you are always left wondering why people have to die in the most bluntest of fashions. Can they just be shot? No, they have to have something impaling them through their eye ball, or rammed into their mouth. That's not a complaint, but just an amusing trait of these films which makes them totally over the top and adorable. I'd definitely recommend this one as its compelling and weird at the same time, making it one of the most novel films of the year, so 'Get Out' there and get in to that cinema :)

I enjoyed this one from first time director Jordan Peele (of Key and Peele fame). The movie is a horror film in a way thats full of suspense, but ultimately a satirical look at race and how people long or act toward one another. The film follows a young photographer named Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya) who along with his girlfriend Rose Armitage (Allison Williams) are visiting her parents together for the first time. Chris is concerned that Rose hasn't told her parents Dean (Bradley Whitford) and Missy (Catherine Keener) that he's a black dude. Chris' best friend Rod (Lil Rel Howery) brings up that he shouldn't go at all since this never ends well (foreshadowing!) Rose see's no concern and they go along on their trip. When they reach her parents house Chris immediately notices some strange things. The help at home are all black people and they act incredibly strange. Rose's younger brother Jeremy (Caleb Landry Jones) who acts very strange. Soon enough Chris is caught up with Missy and her hypnosis which brings him to a strange place called the under. Chris excuses the strange behavior, but soon enough more and more alarming things begin to happen. I'll leave the plot alone there. What I've gone over you can pretty much see on the trailers for the film. The film has a really great kind of method of putting people in Chris' shoes. You see first hand the racism that he encounters at a party with people asking him questions about his strength, or about his "culture." It moves with the story, but the truth is this could have easily been a real life situation for most young black males. The social commentary mixed in with the suspense and horror of the film really mix well. Overall, I was impressed by this one and would definitely recommend giving this one a look!

There's not much more inhumanely horrific than racism and Get Out mixes that fact with acute social commentary, sensitive awareness, and thrilling horror.

The dread is grounded in realism which makes it all the more palpable and tense. This is heightened even more by the peculiar situations and psychological trepidation, before really ramping up for the finale. The acting plays a big role too -- by giving us a range of visceral emotion to subdued reactions and responses, the lead performance shines above all the other quality ones on display.

It's a genre entry that isn't only ace in that regard, but also incorporates layers of vital messages (stealing of black culture, progressive racism, etc.) with keen imagery peppered throughout. I can't wait to see what else Jordan Peele has to offer us in his upcoming films on "other social demons". And in the words of Gambino the Wise...stay woke.

"Intelligent, scary and surprisingly funny, "Get Out" is truly one of the best horror films to come out in years and it's an extraordinary filmmaking debut from writer and director Jordan Peele of "Key & Peele" fame"
Movie Review: Get Out
Date Viewed: March 4 2017
Written and Directed By Jordan Peele
Starring: Daniel Kaluuya, Allison Williams, Bradley Whitford, Catherine Keener, Caleb Landry Jones, Lil Rey Howery, Betty Gabriel, LaKeith Stanfield, Marcus Henderson, Stephen Root and Erika Alexander.

What are you waiting for? Get Out and see "Get Out" because all the buzz and critical acclaim is real. It's truly one of the best horror films to come out in years and it's an extraordinary filmmaking debut from writer and director Jordan Peele of "Key & Peele" fame. It's not only a horror film, it's also a savvy satire as well blending both social and racial issues to the forefront. Sort of a cross between "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" and "The Stepford Wives", "Get Out" centers around a black man who's dating a white woman and when she takes him to meet her parents, the mom and dad start to develop strange behavior around the black man because he's in an interracial relationship with their daughter.

"Get Out" is an intelligent, scary, funny and effectively creepy thrill ride that will make a perfect viewing for any black person who's afraid of police officers and the Trump era. The parents here aren't exactly presented as racists but you will still puzzled and afraid by them anyway. I don't know how Jordan Peele came up with this idea or convinced the studio executives that this concept would make for a great horror flick but he has accomplished the impossible with this film. Even though the year is early, "Get Out" is one of the best movies I've seen this year so far.

The film follows an African-American photographer named Chris Washington (Daniel Kaluuya) as he and his white girlfriend, Rose Armitage (Allison Williams) go on a weekend trip to meet the parents. Chris quickly gets nervous about meeting Rose's parents because it might get uncomfortable and they might be concerned about their daughter dating a black man. When he does meet the parents, Dean and Missy Armitage (Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener), they both seem like nice people with Dean even explaining that he would've voted for Obama if he had to serve a third term. 

The parents introduce Chris to their maid (Betty Gabriel) and groundskeeper (Marcus Henderson) and he immediately notices their strange slave, zombie-like behavior. Dean and Missy seem to be developing strange behavior as well as they ask him questions about his smoking addiction and his late mother. When Missy offers to hypnotize Chris to cure his smoking habit, he thinks that there might be a link between Missy's hypnotizing and the slave-like behavior in the maid and the groundskeeper. 

With a heightened sense of fear, Chris calls his best friend and TSA officer Rod Williams (Lil Rel Howery) for help and he tells him about the unusual behavior that surrounds Rose's parents and their maid and groundskeeper. When Rod looks up online about a months-old disappearance of another black man, Andre Hayworth (LaKeith Stanfield), he warns Chris to get out as fast as possible.

The ending gets a little predictable and soft but nevertheless the big twists in this movie are chilling and the satire works like clockwork. Writer and director Jordan Peele has crafted a horror film that's both clever, witty and stylish. The performances from Daniel Kaluuya, Allison Williams, Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener are all terrific. Kaluuya is the key to the movie because he walks an intense tight-rope of being both charismatic and psychologically afraid.

Even though it's a Blumhouse Production, Jordan Peele doesn't fall for any of the usual genre trappings and he goes all the way with his story which has echoes to classic Hollywood thrillers. "Get Out" is a near-perfect horror film that takes the issues of racism, slavery and other social topics and blends them together to make a biting satire of the black man's fear of the white man.

This was one of my most anticipated movies of 2017 thanks to the fantastically creepy first trailer for this film. When I saw that Jordan Peele from the great sketch comedy show Key & Peele was directing and writing this movie I was even more pumped. Peele is the mastermind behind many of Key & Peele's best sketches, so I knew the potential was there. He is also a huge movie buff, so I was anticipating on seeing many gorgeous shots and camerawork. What I had hoped coming in is what I got coming out, and then some. This film will go down as one of the most important cultural films not just for the Horror genre, but for movies as a whole. The narrative and meaning behind every metaphor and ugly truth is eye-opening, and I feel like we are at the start of a renaissance for black filmmakers. The entire cast was absolutely fantastic, the writing was incredible, and Jordan Peele's direction deserves a standing ovation for a first time filmmaker. We have seen the birth of two new stars in Daniel Kaluuya and Allison Williams, and Lil Rel Howery might've been the biggest surprise to me. He provided the much-needed comedic effect to this very tense film. I will be absolutely shocked if this film isn't nominated for at least two Academy Awards. I was floored walking out of the theater, and I believe Jordan Peele has what it takes to be the next great Director.

I wouldn't have expected someone with their background fully entrenched in comedy to be the main  advertising draw behind a horror movie, but here we are. Following on the heels on his work in Key and Peele and the sometimes-funny-but-overall-disappointing Keanu from last year, Jordan Peele has often been overshadowed by Keegan-Michael Key, but with Get Out, his talents as a storyteller, filmmaker, and satirist display themselves wonderfully. Not only is this one of the most fun movies in recent memory, but it's a brilliant use of the horror genre and its formula and tropes to deliver a biting, twisted racial satire without ever even running the risk of coming off as angry or preachy. It's tense and hilarious in equal measure, making for a Cabin in the Woods-type ride that gradually morphs itself into something crazy à la an Edgar Wright film. Chris (Daniel Kaluuya of the "Fifteen Million Merits" episode of Black Mirror) and Rose (Allison Williams) are a couple going to visit her parents (Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener) for the weekend. She hasn't told them that Chris is black and he's dreading the inevitable awkwardness that will arise from the situation, but she reassures him that they aren't racist. When they all meet, the family seems normally awkward and stilted with dad jokes and a weird younger brother, but Chris is intrigued by their disconcerting black housekeeper Georgina (Betty Gabriel) and the few other black people that he has uncomfortable interactions with. He grows from wary to suspicious of the parents, and to say anything else would likely ruin the experience. The horror genre has been done from so many angles, ranging from lazy and clichéd (endless remakes) to meta and subversive (Scream, The Cabin in the Woods), and the revisionist approach of those included in the latter category often employ a feminist slant. With Get Out, though, the sense of being the "other" is the core of the film. Instead of the male gaze, we experience the white gaze. Instead of having a final girl, we have a final black man. Instead of casual and unintentional misogyny from characters due to ignorance, there's casual and unintentional racism. The discomfort and anxiety is firmly rooted within a viewpoint too often neglected in mainstream movies, and while Jordan Peele's sense of humor is often palpable and makes it a very fun viewing experience, it never strays into parody. This is laser-focused, tonally coherent satire with tricks up its sleeve. We see the humor in how stilted white people can be; there's no denying that behavior typically seen as "bougie" can be off-putting. In addition to cringe-humor, here's also a sense of horror inherent to social anxiety, and this movie fully understands that. This movie doesn't take easy potshots at racism. This family isn't a redneck conservative backwoods type. The mother is a psychiatrist and the father is a neurosurgeon, and the latter has an undying love for Obama. Get Out finds the institutionalized racism that's infected society and then laughs at it with a shrug while maintaining a political but welcoming tone. Comic relief, namely from the work of Lil Rel Howery as Rod, Chris's best friend who is a TSA agent, is the type of accessible humor that's nearly impossible to dislike. The movie's commentary sneaks up on you like a monster in the woods and then gives you a friendly nudge on the shoulder, and the progression of the script and the increasing insanity of what unfolds doesn't let you off the hook. My only issue with Get Out is that it doesn't really have a specific look to it. Other than a few moments of surrealist imagery that reminded me of Scott Pilgrim vs. the World or Under the Skin, oddly enough, the film is pretty generic in color schemes and how it's shot. The visual style is definitely the weakest link here, and really the only flaw that I can think of. Otherwise, this is the best movie that I've seen in months, and it's definitely the best movie of 2017 so far. I'd be really surprised if this didn't make it on my top 10 list come December. 9.2/10, amazing, A, far above average, etc.

It lives up to the 99% Rotten Tomatoes hype. A solid horror/thriller with scares, a cool eerie vibe, humor, and great performances. Jordan Peele's directorial debut looks to be the start of long career behind the camera.

Jordan Peele has it all: an effective premise, characters to care about, consistently funny dialogue, a strong underlying theme, and moments of extreme anxiety. Most horror films do not have that much going, so, for a first-time feature film, Get Out is especially impressive. Perhaps the horror itself is not too frightening upon full realization, but the presentation will be enough to give you the perspective of Chris (Daniel Kaluuya), a black man about to visit his white girlfriend Rose's (Allison Williams) prestigious and even whiter family. Regarding the theme and premise, I do not feel fully comfortable in saying that Get Out offers Chris' full perspective. For Rose's family, it is not enough to welcome black people into their culture. They must literally be able to become black people. This film leaves quite an effective mark in contemporary American society, where many media outlets fail to integrate cultures in a respectful manner. Blatant white supremacy is a dying problem, but the secret supremacy lives on. That is what Rose's family represents, and we see Chris experiencing the extremities of feeling out of control, helpless to the strings of someone with more power, aggravated with how near impossible it seems to share compassion with the more privileged. Mainstream audiences are not often blessed with films like this. This is nice. Bonus points for an interracial sex scene (seriously, I cannot remember the last time I saw a black man and white woman have sex in a film that was not porn), as well as the comedic chops of Bradley Whitford, Catherine Keener, and LilRel Howery.

What manages to elevate this movie beyond simply being a pseudo-remake of Guess Whose Coming to Dinner? is the twists, thrills, and laughs it presents while dealing with the tense subject matter of race in a near perfectly executed subtle manner. It's in the slight dialogue exchanges, the symbolism of a silver spoon, and the fear in a black man's eyes, no longer the fear of a clichéd blonde girl fearing a hyper masculine black man, but that black man's own fears. Peele is not afraid to show fear of suburbia, "diet racism" enjoyed by middle/ upper-class liberals, and exposes a veneer of prejudice among that so often goes unnoticed. Get out of your house and go see Get Out, 2017's best film yet.

Get Out is the directorial debut of Jordan Peele, and it stars Daniel Kaluuya, Allison Williams, Bradley Whitford, and Catherine Keener in a horror film about an interracial couple that is going to see the girlfriend's family, but the issue being, her family doesn't know the fact that her boyfriend is black which certainly got them surprised, and when Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) starts going around the house and sees the people that he met, he starts to get a little suspicious around the place that he's in. Knowing the fact that this is the first film that Jordan Peele has directed and is a horror film, is enough for me to be interested in, and I've been waiting for this to come out on DVD so that I can rent it. Now that I finally got to watch it, Get Out is definitely worth the wait. The acting is fantastic as I haven't seen the main actor in anything which he did great of acting scared and giving out emotional scenes. I finally got to see Allison Williams in something as I kept hearing about her in Girls, and she's great also, and I do like the ambiguity of Bradley Whitford and Catherine Keener as you're not quite sure about what they are, and it's really nice to see them in this as I haven't seen them in a while. The actor that stole the show surprisingly, is Lil Rel Howery as almost every time he's in this, he makes me crack up so much that I can definitely tell that this is Jordan Peele's comedic side in what he sees in his horror elements. I had no idea where it's going, and the scares in this are effective. The characters are likable and memorable, and the climax is crazy in an exciting way. It's really funny in a way that the awkward jokes have the advantage here towards a racial thing going on as white people in this don't know how to talk to the main character, and you feel just as awkward as he is, but in a funny way. There's never a moment that I thought was dumb, and the ending is very good, which there was an alternative ending that was Jordan Peele's original intention, and that was pretty good too. It's thought-provoking, and it gets by the message pretty clear in a subtle messed up way. Get Out is a very strange film that's really original, and is definitely one of those films that I'll watch again.
